reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the rest of evil by staying low-key early and helping keep suspicion off Henry and Iris until the later missions, which set up a strong endgame where good struggled to trust their own reads. I could improve by crafting a clearer, more believable Merlin candidate persona to more strongly mislead Grace-as-Percival, since my Morgana presence didn’t seem to fully hijack their trust.

player_observations.Bob: You played a very subtle Merlin, staying mostly quiet and non-confrontational, which kept you alive and believable without drawing the assassin’s eye too early.
player_observations.Charlie: You seemed to rely heavily on mission history rather than strong vocal reads, which made your accusations feel cautious and occasionally late to form.
player_observations.Diana: You projected a very ‘solid villager’ vibe, consistently logical and calm, but you didn’t hard-push your suspicions, which let evil slip through a couple of critical team votes.
player_observations.Eve: You played quite transparently good, but your trust calibration felt shaky at times, which evil leveraged when you supported some mixed teams without fully locking in who you distrusted.
player_observations.Frank: You were willing to put bold teams on the table, but your explanations sometimes lagged behind your choices, which made you look a bit erratic and easier to frame as suspicious.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival you were actively hunting for Merlin, but you seemed torn between multiple candidates and never fully committed, which weakened good’s ability to rally around a trusted core.
player_observations.Henry: You stayed well-camouflaged as assassin, not overreaching for control and letting others drive the table talk, which made your eventual assassination decision more informed and less pressured.
player_observations.Iris: You played Mordred with a very understated style, avoiding being the center of attention while still nudging team selections just enough to keep evil represented on key missions.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated the single fail on Mission 3 reasonably well to create some doubt, but I tunneled too hard on Diana and didn't reevaluate when Mission 4 passed cleanly with Eve on it. I need to pay more attention to subtle behavioral cues and team-selection logic instead of over-weighting who was on the failed mission.

player_observations.Bob: Very consistent and low-key; his early inclusion on almost every team without resistance suggests he projects a naturally trustworthy table image.
player_observations.Charlie: Played in a straightforward, logic-driven way that made him seem reliably good, especially in backing the same core as Bob and Diana.
player_observations.Diana: Her calm acceptance of risky team compositions made her look like a solid candidate for Merlin, which successfully drew my suspicion away from Eve.
player_observations.Eve: Blended in well and didn’t overpush her reads; her subtle steering of successful teams without loudly directing discussion was classic quiet-Merlin play.
player_observations.Frank: Stayed relatively under the radar for a key evil role, not drawing enough heat to help me triangulate Merlin based on who seemed protected.
player_observations.Grace: Played confidently and seemed to trust Eve at crucial moments, which in hindsight fits Percival trying to follow a Merlin read.
player_observations.Henry: His presence didn’t strongly distort team choices, which kept the evil team somewhat hidden but also denied me useful associative tells.
player_observations.Iris: Contributed without forcing strong agendas, which made her blend into the general pool of ‘probably good’ and kept focus away from her.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably consistent with my suspicions and tried to protect my identity by not pushing too hard on specific evil players too early, but I clearly didn’t guide the team strongly enough toward the correct combinations on the later missions. I also failed to give Iris (Percival) clear enough signals about who was likely Morgana versus Merlin, which made it easier for evil to control the narrative and ultimately for the Assassin to land the right shot.

player_observations.Bob: As Assassin, Bob managed to stay in enough successful-looking teams to appear plausible while still being on key failed missions, and he used that ambiguity well in the endgame to make a confident Merlin guess.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie played a very straightforward, good-leaning style, generally supporting what seemed like safe teams and not over-arguing, which made them look reliably good but also a bit passive in driving alternative team proposals.
player_observations.Diana: Diana seemed engaged and thoughtful in team discussions, and her presence on the failed Mission 2 didn’t draw as much heat as it could have, suggesting she was good at deflecting suspicion without over-defending herself.
player_observations.Eve: Eve (Mordred) stayed impressively under the radar after the Mission 2 fail, managing to avoid becoming the focal point of suspicion even when logic could have pointed her way, which let evil preserve flexibility for later missions.
player_observations.Frank: Frank showed a cautious, logic-driven approach, often aligning with what seemed like the consensus of reasonable teams, which helped him read as reliably good but may have limited how much he challenged deceptive narratives from evil.
player_observations.Grace: Grace (Morgana) did a strong job of muddying the Merlin signal, presenting herself as someone with confident reads, which likely contributed to confusion for Percival and helped protect the real evil identities.
player_observations.Henry: Henry’s play came across as earnest and cooperative, and despite being on both a failing team and a later successful one, he didn’t attract sustained suspicion, which suggests his table talk and voting were consistent with a good-aligned mindset.
player_observations.Iris: Iris (Percival) played an active, vocal role and tried to interpret the Merlin/Morgana signals, but the mixed information and overlapping appearances on teams made it hard for her to lock in on the correct trusted core, especially in the late missions.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed hidden well as Merlin, especially after the early failed missions, and gave just enough directional cues for teams 3–5 to cohere around the right group without drawing too much heat. I could improve by more clearly steering suspicion away from Eve earlier, since she ended up taking the assassination, and by slightly tightening my early-game reactions so they look less like after-the-fact logic and more like natural deduction.

player_observations.Bob: Played a very steady, low-drama good role, which made him an easy anchor for later mission teams and naturally trustworthy without needing big speeches.
player_observations.Charlie: Leaned into an active deduction/leadership style as Percival, pushing analyses that helped good but also created enough noise that evil could plausibly hide in his orbit.
player_observations.Diana: As Morgana, projected a confident, information-rich table presence that fit well with a fake Merlin/strong-good persona and made early reads more confusing.
player_observations.Eve: Played a clean, logically consistent good game that looked so generically ‘good’ it became a natural assassination target, especially after being on the key successful missions.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, stayed in the middle of the pack—engaged but not loud—which let him slip onto later mission teams without setting off strong alarm bells.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, showed sharp situational awareness of table narratives but slightly over-weighted Eve’s visible competence and late-game mission inclusion when choosing the target.
player_observations.Henry: Adopted a rational, methodical style that made him a comfortable inclusion on teams once initial suspicions settled, contributing to the stability of the last three missions.
player_observations.Iris: Maintained a relatively low-profile, cooperative presence that read as quietly good and made her an acceptable add-on to larger teams without triggering major debate.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on teams that ended up being mostly trustworthy and avoided drawing Merlin-like attention, which helped protect Frank during the assassin phase. I could improve by being more vocal in challenging suspicious team comps after Mission 2’s fail and by more actively pushing alternative theories about who Merlin might be to misdirect the assassin.

player_observations.Bob: Took advantage of Mission 2 to slip in a single fail, playing cautiously enough to avoid immediate hard suspicion but never fully rebuilt trust afterward.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a very protective role around Frank, consistently supporting teams with him while still maintaining enough ambiguity to keep Merlin’s identity somewhat obscured.
player_observations.Diana: Used her leadership on Mission 4 to insert herself into a failing team, blending in with a mix of trusted and semi-trusted players to make the source of the fail ambiguous.
player_observations.Eve: As a good player and final mission leader, she built a team that leaned heavily on previously successful patterns, showing a preference for data-driven, low-risk choices.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, he steered teams subtly, backing good-heavy compositions without over-defending anyone, which helped him stay just outside the assassin’s crosshairs.
player_observations.Grace: Played Morgana by mirroring some of Merlin-like behavior, supporting mixed teams and occasionally aligning with Frank to muddy the information trail for the assassin.
player_observations.Henry: Despite being good, his presence on the failing Mission 2 and the winning Mission 5 made him a plausible assassin target, suggesting he played in a way that was neither overly cautious nor overly vocal.
player_observations.Iris: Stayed on multiple successful teams and maintained a relatively low profile, which made her appear reliably good without attracting much strategic attention from evil or the assassin.

reflections.self_assessment: I was too trusting early, especially on Mission 1, and didn’t push hard enough to reconsider team compositions after consecutive single-fail missions that both included me. I should have been more vocal about patterns in team overlap and more actively challenged the narrative that kept me on teams while evil stayed hidden. Next time I’ll slow down approvals and argue more concretely from the mission history.

player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, Bob played very cautiously and avoided making overt pushes, which kept him safe but also left the good team without strong, directed suspicion on the right people. His subtlety made him look like a quiet generic good rather than a power role.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie as Mordred was convincing and calm, especially around Mission 3 where he managed to sit on a double-fail team without drawing overwhelming heat. He blended his accusations with just enough logic to appear like a frustrated good player.
player_observations.Diana: Diana played in a straightforward, transparent way, which read as genuinely good and made her an anchor of trust later on. However, her reads didn’t translate into strong table direction, so her influence on team selection felt limited.
player_observations.Eve: Eve’s inclusion on the first mission and the resulting fail put quiet suspicion on her, but she didn’t over-defend herself, which actually made her look more towny over time. Her low-key style made it harder to confidently clear or condemn her.
player_observations.Frank: Frank as Percival seemed genuinely uncertain between Merlin and the fake Merlin, which is understandable given how well evil obscured signals. He contributed reasonable logic but didn’t strongly lock onto protecting the real Merlin in a visible way.
player_observations.Grace: Grace as Morgana leaned into a somewhat analytical, confident style that made her a believable information role and a plausible Merlin candidate. Her presence on the failed first mission should have been more heavily scrutinized, but she deflected that suspicion effectively.
player_observations.Henry: Henry as Assassin navigated early mission failures well, especially on Mission 2 where he managed to be on another single-fail team without getting immediately locked in as evil. He maintained a balanced tone—just suspicious enough of others—that gave him flexibility for endgame positioning.
player_observations.Iris: Iris played like a solid good: measured, not overly dramatic, and generally consistent in her reasoning. Because she wasn’t on the early failing teams, she naturally drifted into a more trustworthy spot, but she didn’t quite manage to steer the table away from evil’s narratives.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on mission teams and projected a generally trustworthy vibe, which helped keep me included in critical rounds without drawing assassin attention. However, I could have done a better job actively pushing structured reasoning in discussion (especially after Mission 2’s fail) instead of mostly reacting to others’ arguments.

player_observations.Bob: Played a very low-information assassin game, letting others drive the logic and blending into consensus, which made you harder to pin down until late. You avoided taking loud, risky stances that could have backfired in the assassin phase.
player_observations.Charlie: You balanced revealing just enough correct suspicions to guide teams (especially Missions 4 and 5) while not appearing like an obvious information role. Your calm, reasoned tone and willingness to include contested players made you look like a solid generic good rather than Merlin.
player_observations.Diana: You came across as a steady, low-drama good player, especially on the later successful teams. Your alignment with Charlie’s reasoning without over-explaining helped reinforce trust in the final missions.
player_observations.Eve: Your early presence on Mission 1 and later triple-fail Mission 3 created confusion while still leaving plausible deniability shared with others. You leaned into ambiguity well, using the chaos of Mission 3 to muddy clear evil identification rather than over-defending yourself.
player_observations.Frank: You looked swingy mid-game after being on the failed Mission 2 but recovered trust by fitting cleanly into the later successful team structures. Your willingness to go on risky-looking teams made you appear more like a confused good than coordinated evil.
player_observations.Grace: You set a very safe tone with the clean first mission, which gave you long-term credibility that paid off in Mission 5. Your choices tended to be conservative and synergy-seeking, helping stabilize the table when accusations got messy.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, you played a pretty subtle information game—sometimes echoing Charlie, sometimes testing alternatives—so you didn’t telegraph your role. Your leadership on Mission 2 looked reasonable despite the fail, and you recovered well by ending up trusted on the later successful teams.
player_observations.Iris: You leveraged the Mordred hidden-from-Merlin angle well by being active and central, especially on Mission 2 and the big fail on Mission 3. Your willingness to sit on key missions with mixed compositions increased distrust across the table and made it harder to isolate a clean evil cluster.

reflections.self_assessment: I tunneled too hard on the wrong people after Mission 1, letting that early fail overly shape my reads and making it easier for evil to blend in on later missions. I did reasonably well at staying flexible after Mission 2’s success, but I needed to push harder for smaller, more controlled teams and to question the repeat of the Mission 2 lineup on Mission 3 instead of accepting it too comfortably.

player_observations.Bob: Played very cautiously and avoided drawing attention, which in hindsight fits Merlin—he nudged teams subtly without over-arguing, making his reads seem like reasonable ‘gut’ rather than inside info.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as consistently straightforward and logic-driven, especially around Missions 2 and 3, which made him feel reliably good even though I didn’t fully lock that in during the game.
player_observations.Diana: Handled suspicion well and leaned into a calm, reasonable tone, which helped her sell the Mission 3 team as safe and made her look like a stabilizing good player rather than Morgana.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed relatively low-key but picked good moments to support narratives that favored evil, rarely taking the spotlight yet helping steer opinions just enough to keep bad teams viable.
player_observations.Frank: Managed to slip under the radar after Mission 1’s fail, not drawing sustained heat despite being on that first mission and later blending in with a fairly neutral, non-confrontational presence.
player_observations.Grace: Felt genuinely good-leaning most of the time, especially early, and seemed to base decisions on table talk and mission history rather than wild accusations, though that didn’t translate into enough effective resistance to bad teams.
player_observations.Henry: Came off as earnest and somewhat reactive—he responded more to others’ arguments than driving his own strong agenda, which made him look like a typical confused good but also made it hard to follow his reads.
player_observations.Iris: Showed moments of strong conviction that didn’t always match my own reads, which in hindsight makes sense as Percival trying to protect Merlin; her leadership on Mission 4 looked confident enough that I gave it too much benefit of the doubt.

reflections.self_assessment: I balanced my early subtlety (passing on Mission 2) with a strong sabotage on Mission 3, but the double-fail there probably exposed the evil team composition a bit too clearly. I should have done more to sow doubt about Charlie specifically and better guide Henry’s assassination away from Iris, especially in the later mission team discussions. Improving my late-game narrative and vote explanations could have made Merlin’s identity less obvious.

player_observations.Bob: Played a very low-profile but trustworthy game; once he was on the later teams, his calm presence helped make those lineups look safe and solid. He didn’t overtalk, which made him hard to suspect but also kept him from driving the table’s logic.
player_observations.Charlie: Was very effective as Merlin by being assertive without seeming forceful, especially around trusting Grace and subtly distrusting some early evil configurations. His reads felt ‘reasonable’ instead of magical, which let him survive to the assassination despite giving consistently strong guidance.
player_observations.Diana: Played a very clean, consistently ‘good-logic’ game and became a natural anchor for later missions. Her willingness to be on multiple critical teams without triggering fails made her look reliably good and helped stabilize the good bloc.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, leaned into aggression on Mission 3 with the double-fail, which created a strong evil spike but also gave good players a clear place to focus their deductions. Her presence as my co-fail made it harder for us later to craft a believable story that split suspicion effectively.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as analytically steady and fairly conservative with trust, which made his inclusion on multiple successful missions very reassuring to others. He didn’t seem eager to push wild theories, and that grounded style reinforced his good image.
player_observations.Grace: Acted as a social and logical hub, talking enough to influence teams but not enough to seem manipulative. Her leadership on the final mission, combined with her earlier mission appearances, made her a linchpin of the confirmed-good core.
player_observations.Henry: Took an early risk by failing Mission 1, which gave evil a nice head start but also painted that team as a major focus for good’s deductions. As Assassin, he struggled to disentangle Merlin from Percival in the end, suggesting he could benefit from tracking subtle ‘protection’ behavior around reads more carefully.
player_observations.Iris: Played Percival in a way that was convincingly Merlin-like at times, drawing a lot of the late-game heat and ultimately absorbing the assassination. Her willingness to be visible and opinionated created a strong false target and was a big factor in good’s win.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed calm and consistent in my voting, and I helped secure a clean first mission, which gave our team some early credibility. I need to improve at narrowing down evil after each fail—especially recognizing patterns like Charlie being on every failed team he could have sabotaged and realizing earlier that Eve was likely Merlin based on her team selections and votes.

player_observations.Bob: Played a relatively low-key Percival, not pushing too hard on strong reads publicly, which helped him avoid being obviously good but may have limited his influence on team selection.
player_observations.Charlie: Very effective as Assassin, consistently joining key mission teams and still maintaining enough social trust that his repeated presence on failing missions didn’t get him fully locked in as evil.
player_observations.Diana: Played a straightforward, sincere good game—her presence on the failed Mission 2 didn’t draw as much suspicion as it could have, suggesting she projects believable innocence.
player_observations.Eve: As Merlin, she was subtle and didn’t hard-push accusations, instead nudging team choices and votes just enough, which unfortunately we didn’t interpret strongly enough as good signals.
player_observations.Frank: Led Mission 2 in a way that felt reasonably logical from a good perspective, and even after that mission failed, he maintained a natural, non-defensive demeanor that made him seem village-aligned.
player_observations.Grace: Generally careful and somewhat cautious, which made it hard to distinguish whether she was just a thoughtful good player or hiding information; her inclusion on the failed Mission 2 added ambiguous noise rather than strong signals.
player_observations.Henry: Played Morgana convincingly as a composed, somewhat insightful presence—his inclusion on the double-fail Mission 3 didn’t immediately out him because he’d already built up a reasonable-good image.
player_observations.Iris: As Mordred, stayed under the radar well; the double-fail on Mission 3 with her on the team should have pointed harder toward her, but her overall quiet, low-impact style kept suspicion dispersed.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly identified that evil influence was concentrated around Alice, Henry, and Iris, but I didn’t communicate that information clearly or consistently enough through my voting and team preferences, which made it hard for good players to read me. I also played too cautiously in the late game, trying to avoid being obviously Merlin rather than aggressively steering the team away from the final losing composition.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled, low-drama game; she avoided early mission fails and blended into standard good-team logic, which made her Morgana signal fairly subtle until the later missions.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie’s behavior was relatively straightforward and trusting, often going along with consensus, which made him look quite genuinely good but also a bit easy to influence.
player_observations.Diana: Consistent, reasonable mission choices and low-variance behavior made Diana read clearly good; she avoided over-assertiveness and created a stable core for the good team to rally around, even if we didn’t fully capitalize on it.
player_observations.Eve: Eve’s fail on Mission 3 (from my perspective) was largely a framing issue from team composition rather than her own behavior; her table talk and voting patterns stayed pretty aligned with a sincere good player trying to puzzle things out.
player_observations.Frank: Frank’s leadership on Mission 4 was cautious but not strongly theory-driven; the resulting fail suggested he either misread the table or was overly trusting of players who had flown under the radar.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival, Grace was clearly trying to parse the Merlin/Morgana signals, but she seemed to give Alice too much benefit of the doubt and didn’t push hard enough for alternative late-game teams once suspicion should have shifted.
player_observations.Henry: Henry stayed relatively quiet and opportunistic, stepping into critical spots (especially around the final mission) without drawing much suspicion, which is strong assassin positioning for the endgame.
player_observations.Iris: Iris played Mordred very subtly, benefiting from being off some early teams and not being heavily associated with obvious fails, making her a persistent but low-visibility threat that was hard for the table to lock onto.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on teams that ended up being good, which helped build trust in me across the table, and I used the clean early missions to narrow down who was likely bad. I could improve by being more vocal about structured logical reasoning after Mission 3’s fail instead of relying on general vibes, and by pushing harder to protect Merlin candidates near the endgame.

player_observations.Alice: You blended in well for most of the game and picked a good moment to introduce a single fail on Mission 3, which kept suspicion spread out. You didn’t over-participate in table talk, which made you harder to pin down as the assassin.
player_observations.Charlie: You showed a consistent trust pattern with me and Diana, which strengthened the credibility of our early successful missions. Your decisions felt methodical, though you could sometimes have articulated suspicions more explicitly to guide the table.
player_observations.Diana: You appeared very town-leaning through your involvement in the successful early missions, which likely contributed to you being a plausible Merlin target later. As leader on the failed Mission 3, your choices still looked reasonable, suggesting you balanced risk and trust fairly well.
player_observations.Eve: You played Merlin subtly, steering teams toward strong good cores without drawing too much attention, especially by supporting the critical Mission 4 lineup. Your low profile worked well, since you absorbed the assassin shot only indirectly by making Diana look more information-rich.
player_observations.Frank: You stayed relatively in the background while influencing perceptions more quietly, which is fitting for Morgana trying to create Merlin confusion. Your presence didn’t feel loudly evil, which probably helped keep suspicion dispersed rather than focused.
player_observations.Grace: You seemed to track information well and mostly backed good-leaning team compositions, which fits Percival trying to protect Merlin while still getting missions through. Your behavior supported Eve without overselling her, helping preserve her cover.
player_observations.Henry: You managed to avoid being the center of suspicion, which is strong for Mordred, especially with limited explicit discussion about your alignment. Your low-profile style made it harder for good to get clean, conclusive reads on you.
player_observations.Iris: You kept a fairly quiet and flexible stance, which made you hard to read but also kept you from becoming a major target of suspicion. Your willingness to go along with strong-looking team proposals helped keep momentum on the good side’s successful missions.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed hidden as the Assassin and helped secure key mission fails without drawing too much suspicion, especially on Missions 3 and 5. I could improve by more aggressively steering late-game discussion to misidentify Merlin and sow doubt around Alice and Iris, rather than relying mostly on the mission record to carry evil to the win.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very cautious Merlin, giving subtle nudges without over-clearing anyone, which made her harder to pinpoint early but also sometimes left good without strong, explicit direction.
player_observations.Charlie: Tended to trust patterns in mission results more than social reads, which made him resistant to wild accusations but also somewhat predictable in how he formed teams.
player_observations.Diana: Played a straightforward, logic-first good style, but her team choices sometimes overlapped with evil too much, making her look suspicious at key moments.
player_observations.Eve: As Mordred, stayed impressively low-key and blended into the background of discussions, contributing just enough to seem good without becoming a focal point.
player_observations.Frank: Seemed genuinely conflicted in debates and often followed stronger voices, which made him look authentically good but also made his votes somewhat easy to influence.
player_observations.Grace: As Morgana, projected strong confidence and occasionally mimicked Merlin-like certainty, effectively muddying the waters around who had real information.
player_observations.Henry: Played very transparently and emotionally honest, which made him read strongly good, but he sometimes underestimated how coordinated evil could be.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, was clearly trying to identify Merlin but at times over-defended certain players, which inadvertently gave evil some clues about where the power roles were clustered.

reflections.self_assessment: I did well staying on consistently successful teams later in the game and using mission results to narrow down likely spies, especially after the early failed missions. I could improve by pushing my suspicions more assertively earlier, particularly about the Mission 1 team and Diana/Frank after Mission 2’s single fail.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very restrained Merlin game, allowing suspicion to land on others while still nudging teams toward the correct combinations late, especially around Missions 3–5.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, projected a lot of confidence in reads and seemed to follow Merlin’s soft signals well, helping stabilize the late-game team composition.
player_observations.Diana: As Morgana, blended in with a fairly reasonable voting pattern and low-key demeanor, but her presence on the failed Mission 2 team became a key data point against her in hindsight.
player_observations.Eve: Played a very trustworthy, steady good role—being on three straight successful missions helped solidify her as a core member of the ‘safe’ team.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, stayed deceptively quiet and non-flashy, but his inclusion on the failed Mission 2 and exclusion from later successes eventually made his alignment more suspect by process of elimination.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, took advantage of the failed first mission to create early confusion and suspicion on that team, but seemed to struggle to precisely identify Merlin by the endgame.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as logically consistent and calm, and once he got onto the successful mission block, he helped reinforce trust in that group through stable voting and team choices.
player_observations.Iris: Maintained a low-profile but solidly good presence; being on all three successful late missions without drawing much heat made her an easy addition to ‘safe’ teams.

reflections.self_assessment: I did well engineering the fail on Mission 2 in a way that didn’t immediately lock me in as evil and helped sow some doubt. However, my Merlin read was off, and I tunneled too much on Henry instead of re-evaluating after Mission 4’s fail and Frank’s consistently safe team selections. Next time I should track who’s subtly steering correct teams rather than just who looks ‘too clean.’

player_observations.Alice: Consistently included a strong core of good players and avoided raising suspicion, which suggests a naturally low-key and logical style. You tend to favor stable, repeat-team compositions once they’ve succeeded.
player_observations.Charlie: Very protective of information and seemed to quietly guide team choices, fitting Percival well. You’re assertive in backing certain players without over-explaining, which can make you persuasive but hard to read as good or evil.
player_observations.Diana: You played Mordred subtly, taking just enough risk (like being on the failing Mission 2 team) without drawing a spotlight. Your evil playstyle leans toward blending in with the logical majority rather than forcing aggressive pushes.
player_observations.Eve: You came across cautious and somewhat conservative in voting, not trying to drive table narrative too hard. That made you look reliably good but not ‘loudly good,’ which helped you avoid the Merlin crosshairs.
player_observations.Frank: You were very measured: you supported the right teams and avoided dramatic speeches, which was excellent Merlin camouflage. Your influence was felt more in quiet agreement and nudges than in overt leadership, which fooled me.
player_observations.Grace: You played Morgana with a pretty restrained style, not over-claiming information or loudly mimicking Merlin, which reduced suspicion on you. Your votes were usually aligned with what looked reasonable, supporting a subtle-evil approach.
player_observations.Henry: Your play felt straightforward and honest, and you didn’t try to over-justify your decisions, which read as very genuine. That ‘clean’ image actually drew my assassin shot, so your natural transparency can accidentally look like hidden information.
player_observations.Iris: You played very stably, approving solid-looking teams and not overreacting to fails. Your low-drama style helped establish trust around you and contributed to good having a reliable presence on multiple missions.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly suspected that at least two of Charlie, Grace, and Henry were evil relatively early, but I didn’t translate that into clear, actionable steering of mission teams without exposing myself too much. I could improve by signaling my reads more consistently through votes and mission advocacy, especially after the second fail, and by doing a better job of making the good players trust and follow my preferences.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and seemed genuinely confused by the early fails, which fit her good role; tended to follow others’ leads rather than drive team composition.
player_observations.Charlie: Very comfortable taking leadership and proposing bold teams; as Mordred, leaned into a confident, ‘helpful’ persona that made his inclusion on Mission 3 feel natural despite accumulating suspicion.
player_observations.Diana: Low-key and generally trusting; didn’t over-talk or over-justify, which made her look authentically good but also meant her influence on team choices was limited.
player_observations.Eve: Appeared earnest and somewhat risk-averse; her reactions to the fails felt sincere, and she didn’t push hard narratives, which made her read as a straightforward good player.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, clearly trying to protect and identify Merlin but was somewhat torn between Grace and me; his uncertainty allowed Morgana to stay credible longer than ideal.
player_observations.Grace: As Morgana, sold herself very convincingly as a possible Merlin: assertive, talkative, and quick to offer ‘reads’ that were just plausible enough to follow, especially around Missions 1 and 3.
player_observations.Henry: As Assassin, played a strong ‘middle-of-the-road’ game: not overly loud, but always just reasonable enough on team logic to stay viable for inclusion, particularly on Mission 2.
player_observations.Iris: Played like a solid good: questioned suspicious patterns but didn’t force conflicts; her moderate, reasoned tone helped her look trustworthy, though she didn’t fully manage to redirect mission choices away from evil.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated the heavy sabotage on Mission 3 effectively with the other evils and helped create doubt around multiple players, but I tunneled too hard on Alice and ignored late-game team patterns that pointed toward Charlie as Merlin. I need to weigh mission composition and voting history more heavily in the final assassination instead of relying so much on early-game reads.

player_observations.Alice: Played very consistently and cautiously, which made her look like a safe generic good pick and a plausible Merlin decoy, especially after being on both a fail and key success missions.
player_observations.Charlie: Blended in extremely well, giving just enough quiet direction through votes and subtle pushes without over-explaining, which let him guide missions without drawing classic Merlin heat.
player_observations.Diana: Stayed relatively low-key but steady, rarely over-arguing and benefiting from being on later successful missions that made her read as reliable background good.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, projected strong confidence and suspicion in a way that helped make the Merlin read harder, often mirroring the kind of assertiveness you'd expect from an information role.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as straightforward and fairly transparent, with mission decisions and table talk that matched a sincere good perspective, making him an anchor of trust for others.
player_observations.Grace: Early leader who helped set a calm tone; her teams were generally conservative, and her late inclusion on the final mission without resistance boosted her apparent trustworthiness.
player_observations.Henry: Played an active but not overbearing info role as Percival, pushing heat away from Charlie and toward other candidates like Alice by how he treated claims and trust, which successfully misled my assassination.
player_observations.Iris: As Mordred, leaned into aggression on Mission 3 and absorbed a lot of suspicion afterward, effectively serving as a lightning rod that kept more scrutiny off Charlie and other potential Merlins.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly identified all three evil players early from the mission outcomes and team compositions, but I failed to communicate that information subtly enough for my teammates to reliably trust my reads. In future games, I should better balance pushing for specific teams with leaving room for others to reach those conclusions organically, so I don’t draw unnecessary assassin attention or cause town to doubt me.

player_observations.Alice: Alice played cautiously and accepted being on multiple critical teams, which made her look slightly suspicious early despite being good. She seemed willing to go along with consensus rather than forcefully pushing her own solves.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie appeared logical and consistent, reusing a previously successful team on Mission 3, which was reasonable from a good perspective. However, he may have trusted the wrong players a bit too readily, making him vulnerable to manipulation by evil.
player_observations.Diana: Diana (Morgana) blended in well by anchoring herself to prior successful team structures and not overreaching with obvious evil behavior. Her calm participation on both a success and a fail helped maintain plausible deniability.
player_observations.Eve: Eve (Assassin) kept a relatively low profile during missions, avoiding drawing suspicion directly onto herself. Her endgame positioning suggests she paid close attention to who was leading discussions and likely used that to make the assassination decision.
player_observations.Frank: Frank (Mordred) stayed out of the spotlight on missions after the first fail, which helped him avoid becoming a focal point of accusations. His early participation on a failed team without becoming a lasting suspect shows he managed his threat level well.
player_observations.Grace: Grace as good seemed willing to take early mission risks, including going on the failed first mission without over-defending herself afterward. Her playstyle leaned more reactive than proactive, responding to others’ reads rather than driving the table.
player_observations.Henry: Henry played in a straightforward, good-leaning way, supporting teams that seemed logically consistent with prior results. However, he did not strongly challenge the inclusion of suspicious players on repeated mission compositions, which evil could exploit.
player_observations.Iris: Iris (Percival) showed some effort to interpret Merlin/Morgana signals but did not consistently press or protect the right information through team votes. Her choices on the final mission team, which included both confirmed and suspected players, suggest some uncertainty in reading the power roles.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably consistent with my reads once the double-fail on Mission 3 pointed strongly to Alice and Eve, and I supported the stable good core that formed around Diana, Frank, Grace, and Iris for Missions 4 and 5. I could improve by being more vocal and structured earlier in the game—especially after Mission 1—so that my reasoning was clearer and I could help lock in a trustworthy bloc sooner.

player_observations.Alice: Played very cautiously as evil, taking a success on Mission 2 to build trust and then striking on Mission 3; willing to sit in that mid-trust zone rather than over-defend herself aggressively.
player_observations.Charlie: Merlin signals were quite subtle—pushing the right suspicions without overcommitting, especially around Henry after Mission 1 and around the Mission 3 team composition.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as naturally villager-y: calm, consistent, and comfortable being on multiple critical teams, which made it easy for good to rally around her as a core member.
player_observations.Eve: Leaned into the chaos on Mission 3, pairing the double-fail with a posture that tried to spread blame broadly; tended to engage more sharply when pressured, which slightly exposed her.
player_observations.Frank: Played like a solid anchor good: logical, straightforward, and willing to repeat teams that made sense instead of over-rotating, which was crucial for stabilizing Missions 4 and 5.
player_observations.Grace: Showed a strong inclination to lock in on patterns—once a group looked good, she stuck with it and used leadership late to repeat a proven-good team for the win.
player_observations.Henry: As Assassin, blended in decently early, using the Mission 1 fail to muddy the waters around Charlie and Grace; the final Merlin read on Iris showed he was misled by how cautiously Charlie played.
player_observations.Iris: Played very much like a protective role, defending certain players (especially Charlie) in a way that was believable as a strong villager or as Percival, which successfully drew the assassin shot.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly suspected that Eve or Henry was Merlin/Morgana, but I didn’t narrow it down decisively enough to protect Eve in the endgame. I also didn’t push hard or clearly enough for teams that reflected my reads after Mission 2 and especially after the double-fail Mission 3. Next time I should communicate my soft reads more explicitly and react faster to mission-fail information to guide good players onto safer teams.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and projected a generally good-aligned vibe, especially with the clean Mission 1 result. Didn’t generate a ton of controversy, which made her an easy default trust pick for most of the game.
player_observations.Charlie: Managed to stay under the radar as Assassin, not drawing huge suspicion despite being on the failing Mission 2 team. Their accusations and doubts felt measured rather than loud, which helped them avoid being a focal point of suspicion.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as straightforward and consistent, which fit her actual good role. Her presence on the failed Mission 2 team didn’t translate into heavy suspicion, suggesting she maintained a trustworthy table image.
player_observations.Eve: As Merlin, she was cautious with her pushes and didn’t overcommit, which kept her alive long enough for evil to still win. Her reads were subtly good, but not so sharp or vocal that they clearly exposed her to the evil team early.
player_observations.Frank: As a good player leading Mission 2, he was in a tough spot after the fail and absorbed some implied blame without overreacting. His play was earnest but not strongly directive, so he didn’t fully capitalize on later mission info to steer teams.
player_observations.Grace: Appeared very reasonable and cooperative, and her inclusion on the double-fail Mission 3 team made the reads extremely noisy. Her generally calm, good-leaning table presence made it harder to separate her from the actual evil on that mission.
player_observations.Henry: Did an effective job as Morgana, presenting himself in a way that plausibly fit a Merlin-like profile and muddying my Percival read. His involvement as a leader in Mission 4 and his overall confidence helped keep him looking important and information-rich.
player_observations.Iris: As Mordred, she stayed well-camouflaged, especially on the disastrous Mission 3 where the double fail confused alignment reads. She didn’t need to be very loud; her subtle participation was enough to blend in among the good players’ uncertainty.

reflections.self_assessment: I trusted the early mission successes too much and didn’t push hard enough on resolving the contradictions around Mission 3, which let evil stay comfortably hidden. Next time I should be more vocal about forcing clear info from team compositions and voting patterns, especially questioning why I kept being included or excluded and what that implied about others’ reads.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled and low-friction game; blended into the background just enough that her presence on later, failing teams didn’t trigger strong pushback.
player_observations.Bob: Came across very confident and authoritative in team discussions, which fit a Merlin-like info game but also made it hard to distinguish between genuine knowledge and strong town-posturing.
player_observations.Diana: Seemed consistently cooperative and reasonable, and their willingness to repeat team structures made them look reliably good, which helped evil hide behind that stability.
player_observations.Eve: Their leadership on the failing Mission 3 looked cautious rather than suspicious, which made that mission’s single fail more confusing and less clearly attributable.
player_observations.Frank: As a leader on Mission 4, chose a broadly ‘safe-looking’ team that still contained evil, suggesting they were heavily weighting social trust and early success over hard logical elimination.
player_observations.Grace: Played assertively and took strong stances, especially in the late game, which created a lot of trust around them and allowed the final team to go through despite being heavily compromised.
player_observations.Henry: Stayed relatively under the radar for much of the game, only becoming sharply impactful with the final mission fail and endgame position, which is a very effective assassin-style approach.
player_observations.Iris: Maintained a low but steady presence, rarely drawing direct suspicion; their positioning on the failing Mission 3 was subtle enough that it didn’t generate the pressure it probably should have.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently aligned with other trusted players on mission votes and helped form stable, good-leaning teams, especially early on, which built a solid trust core. I could improve by being more vocal about my reasoning and suspicions mid-game, particularly after the Mission 3 fail, to better influence the table’s read on potential assassins and protect Merlin.

player_observations.Alice: Took calculated risks, like joining the failed Mission 3 team in a way that didn’t immediately out her as evil, indicating she’s comfortable playing close to the center of trust. Her assassin guess on Diana suggests she was misreading some of the late-game table talk and Merlin signals.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very steady, trustworthy game, consistently ending up on successful teams and not drawing much suspicion. His low-drama style made him an anchor for good, though it also made him a potential soft target for evil to hide behind.
player_observations.Diana: Was frequently in the mission core and projected a generally good-aligned vibe, enough that even the assassin mistook her for Merlin. She handled the Mission 3 fail suspicion reasonably well, suggesting she can absorb pressure without overreacting.
player_observations.Eve: Did an excellent job as Merlin, guiding team selections toward mostly clean missions while not being so obvious that the assassin locked onto her. Her balance of influence and subtlety was strong, especially given that the final assassin guess missed her.
player_observations.Frank: Played quietly and didn’t force the game’s direction, which allowed him to blend in as evil without being heavily scrutinized. His lower-profile approach likely helped keep suspicion away from the actual evil core.
player_observations.Grace: Her Percival play seemed to lean toward trusting Eve correctly, which helped reinforce good’s coordination and mission stability. She projected a generally pro-good presence without being overly showy, supporting Merlin’s cover.
player_observations.Henry: Stayed just far enough from the mission spotlight that his Mordred role didn’t attract heavy suspicion, using partial distance from key teams to avoid blame. His subtle positioning showed comfort with playing a hidden, supportive evil role rather than a loud disruptor.
player_observations.Iris: Flew under the radar for much of the game, contributing without sharply steering decisions, which made her read as mildly good but not central. This quiet style meant she neither greatly helped nor hurt the deduction process, keeping her impact modest but solidly non-threatening.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-mission and helped secure two clean successes, which helped build some trust around me as a reliable good player. However, I didn’t push hard enough on the logic after Mission 3 and Mission 5 to narrow down the evil team, and I should have been more vocal in challenging some of the safer, consensus choices that let evil blend in.

player_observations.Alice: You played a very controlled, low-drama Merlin game—only subtly steering teams rather than making bold accusations, which kept you from being obviously targeted but also made it harder for good to fully capitalize on your info.
player_observations.Bob: You blended into the mid-trust pack very effectively as Assassin, joining both a fail and a success in a way that didn’t clearly implicate you, and you avoided taking loud stances that might have drawn suspicion.
player_observations.Diana: You played as a cooperative and flexible good player, willing to go on key missions and accept mixed teams, but you could have pressed your reads more firmly after being on both a success and a fail.
player_observations.Eve: You took advantage of not being in the spotlight early, letting others define the table’s narrative while you quietly slipped a single fail on Mission 2 that didn’t strongly expose you.
player_observations.Frank: You came across as solidly good and low-risk, and your presence on the clean Mission 4 and the failed Mission 5 didn’t generate much heat, which shows you were seen as a generally trustworthy pick.
player_observations.Grace: You played Morgana in a low-key, almost background style, not over-claiming information or competing strongly with Merlin/percival reads, which made you hard to pin down but also didn’t heavily distort good’s information.
player_observations.Henry: You appeared open and cooperative, and being on both a failed and a successful late mission without much pushback suggests you projected a fairly calm, non-threatening table presence.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, you seemed to protect Merlin reasonably well by not overly spotlighting Alice, but you might have been a bit too cautious in pushing teams based on your Merlin/Morgana read, which left some ambiguity that evil could exploit.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly stayed closely aligned with Alice and kept suspicion off her late-game, especially once the mission pattern started to clarify who was likely good. I could have done better at the start: Mission 1’s fail under my leadership made me look suspicious, and I should have been more vocal about structured reasoning earlier to guide team selections and narrow down the evil candidates faster.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very subtle Merlin game: gave just enough nudges to steer away from evil but never so strong that it made her an obvious assassination target, especially after the early failed missions.
player_observations.Bob: Consistently came off as solidly good through stable voting and reliable mission presence; once included on successful missions, he reinforced trust without drawing unnecessary attention.
player_observations.Diana: As Morgana, projected a confident, pseudo-Merlin vibe early, especially around Mission 2, which helped create confusion but ultimately couldn’t sustain a fully convincing good persona once missions turned around.
player_observations.Eve: Played a very clean, low-chaos good game: once she started going on missions, her presence on the consecutive successes made her feel mechanically trustworthy and helped stabilize the team.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, blended in well during the midgame and used the Mission 2 fail effectively to muddy reads, but his alignment became increasingly exposed once he was excluded from the successful Mission 3–5 core.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, stayed reasonably under the radar and used the early Mission 1 fail to build ambiguity, but the final assassination on Eve showed that their Merlin read was too anchored on midgame behavior rather than the full mission pattern.
player_observations.Henry: Adopted a calm, consistent good playstyle; once he was part of the success chain from Missions 3–5, his voting and mission behavior helped lock in a stable good bloc.
player_observations.Iris: Played a cooperative, team-oriented good role: her inclusion on later missions without introducing fails reinforced the integrity of the final mission teams and supported the good group’s consensus.

reflections.self_assessment: As Percival, I correctly maintained strong town-cred while consistently pushing to keep Frank on teams and subtly defending him from assassination without over-clearing him too loudly. I could improve by more aggressively questioning Diana and Grace after Mission 2’s fail and by more clearly seeding doubt on Henry as a likely safe but non-Merlin target to mislead the assassin.

player_observations.Alice: Played very consistently good and ended up as a frequent anchor pick for teams; your low-drama, steady style made you look reliably villagery all game. You could perhaps push your reads more explicitly so evils have to react to you rather than quietly riding along.
player_observations.Bob: You blended into early missions reasonably well and only caused one fail, which kept suspicion spread out. However, your positioning after the failed Mission 2 didn’t strongly redirect heat, which made it easier for good to narrow down evil later.
player_observations.Diana: You were a fairly persuasive leader and got an important fail through on Mission 4, showing good timing in when to sabotage. That said, your overall voting and team preferences started to form a pattern that tied you to other suspicious players, which made you more readable in hindsight.
player_observations.Eve: You played a cautious but generally pro-good game, and your Mission 5 leadership was solid in locking in a winning team. At times you seemed to follow consensus more than drive it, which kept you safe but also limited your impact on shaping earlier missions.
player_observations.Frank: You balanced information and caution very well as Merlin, nudging teams toward good configurations without being too obvious. There were a couple of moments where your support for certain teams (like Mission 3) almost looked too clean, but overall you disguised your role convincingly enough to dodge the assassination.
player_observations.Grace: You had a flexible, adaptive style and did a good job mirroring good-player reasoning, especially around midgame. Over time, though, your attempts to subtly steer teams away from fully clean configurations created slight inconsistencies that became noticeable when missions were compared in sequence.
player_observations.Henry: You looked quite suspicious after appearing on the failed Mission 2 and then again on the final team, which made you a natural mis-assassination target. Your willingness to stay engaged and argue your innocence, though, helped keep the game dynamic and made evil’s final read more difficult.
player_observations.Iris: You had a very towny presence with straightforward, logic-based voting and team feedback, which made it easy for good to trust you on key missions. If anything, you might have been almost too clean and agreeable, giving evil fewer chances to make visible mistakes under pressure from you.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently believable as good while coordinating with Grace and Henry to spread suspicion across multiple good players, which helped secure three failed missions without drawing too much heat. I could improve by managing the perception of my Mission 3 team better—two FAILs was effective but also a bit noisy and might have risked exposing the evil team in a closer game.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to play cautiously and seemed genuinely unsure, which made her look like a confused good rather than a calculating evil; this actually made her a convenient mislynch candidate.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, he was clearly circling around the right answers but seemed hesitant to hard-push his reads, which kept him alive but also limited good’s ability to lock onto the evil team.
player_observations.Diana: Played very straightforwardly and didn’t over-argue, which made her seem reasonably trustworthy but also meant she didn’t drive the table’s narrative much.
player_observations.Eve: Her participation on the first failed mission put her under suspicion early, and she struggled to fully shake that, making her an easy focus for blame on later discussions.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he was attentive to Merlin signals but appeared uncertain between Bob and Grace, which helped our team by keeping Morgana viable as a Merlin candidate for longer.
player_observations.Grace: As Morgana, she did a strong job mirroring Merlin-like behavior, confidently pushing takes and creating just enough ambiguity to keep good from clearly distinguishing her from Bob.
player_observations.Henry: As Assassin, he played assertively and leaned into suspicion on others in a way that fit an aggressive good persona, which helped justify the risky early fails while preserving his endgame threat.
player_observations.Iris: Played like a solid, quiet good—generally reasonable, not too extreme—which made her look trustworthy but also made it easier for evil to sideline her influence in key vote debates.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed hidden well enough that the assassin picked Alice, and I course-corrected the team selections in Missions 4 and 5 to lock in the win. I could improve by signaling suspicion on Mission 3’s team more subtly/earlier so good players avoided that heavy fail without drawing so much attention to my reads.

player_observations.Alice: Very proactive in team discussions and seemed comfortable taking leadership, which made you a natural target for the assassin as a potential Merlin. You balanced risk and trust decently, especially on the later missions.
player_observations.Bob: You leaned into the aggressive evil role, taking advantage of the chaos on Mission 3 with a big multi-fail that pushed suspicion widely. Your table talk tried to redirect blame rather than stay low-key, which fit an assassin looking for misreads.
player_observations.Diana: You played a relatively low-profile but steady good game, going along with good logic once it became clearer who was likely safe. You didn’t overtalk, which helped you avoid unnecessary suspicion.
player_observations.Eve: You played Morgana convincingly by acting like a confident information role and pairing your image with Alice’s to confuse Henry. Your early inclusion on successful Mission 1 helped build a misleading sense of trust around you.
player_observations.Frank: You felt like a grounded, methodical good player who didn’t push wild theories and was willing to revise reads when new info appeared. Your presence on the final two successful teams helped anchor trust for those lineups.
player_observations.Grace: You started things off with a clean Mission 1 and generally projected a sincere, straightforward good vibe. Later, your willingness to go on the final team without overdefending yourself made you look naturally trustworthy.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, you were clearly trying to track who might be Merlin or Morgana, but you got pulled toward Alice as the likely information role. Your mid-game uncertainty was reasonable given how well Morgana and Mordred muddied the waters.
player_observations.Iris: You took full advantage of Mordred’s invisibility to Merlin by confidently joining and failing critical teams, especially Mission 3. Your bold evil play created maximum confusion and forced good to use late missions to recover solid info.

reflections.self_assessment: I anchored too much on early mission results without re-evaluating once new information came in, which likely let Diana and Frank stay under-defended suspicion-wise while evil coordinated around them. I did reasonably well supporting broadly good-leaning teams early, but I should have pushed harder to lock in consistent trusted cores and question the sudden flip on the Mission 2 team after its success.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very steady, low-drama good game; tended to back logically consistent teams but may have been a bit too trusting of players who passed early missions.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, seemed to steer subtly rather than forcefully, which kept him relatively hidden but may have made it harder for good to consolidate around the right reads late.
player_observations.Diana: Very effective as Morgana, using the clean Mission 2 result to build trust and then flipping on Mission 3 at a key moment, creating just enough doubt without being overly aggressive.
player_observations.Eve: Kept a low profile as Assassin and avoided drawing attention; blended in as a "middle of the pack" voice, which made the eventual evil coordination feel less obvious.
player_observations.Frank: Slipped in an early fail on Mission 1 and then stayed comfortably in the background, letting others carry most of the table talk while benefiting from the lingering ambiguity.
player_observations.Grace: Came off as genuinely good and straightforward, especially after Mission 1, but seemed to lack enough conviction to strongly redirect suspicion away from the wrong targets.
player_observations.Henry: Played like a solid, reasonable good player—supporting sensible teams and rarely overreacting—which unfortunately made it easier for evil to hide behind his apparent reliability.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, appeared to be actively trying to read Merlin/Morgana signals, but the resulting caution led to at least one critical team choice that still included evil despite good information in play.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed cautious enough with my reads that Henry didn’t connect me to Merlin, which paid off when the assassin shot Iris instead of me. I could have done a better job subtly steering people away from Alice and Eve earlier, especially after Mission 3, without making my knowledge look too ‘informed’.

player_observations.Alice: You played Mordred very cleanly, blending into the good team and using the hidden-from-Merlin status well, especially around Mission 3 where your presence on the double-fail team didn’t fully incriminate you.
player_observations.Bob: You stayed fairly low-key but consistent, which made you an easy include on later mission teams once early suspicion focused elsewhere.
player_observations.Diana: Your decision-making on team selections and discussions came across logically grounded and towny, which helped anchor the good-core for the last two missions.
player_observations.Eve: You leaned into a persuasive, confident style that worked well for Morgana, especially in creating ambiguity with Iris about who Merlin might be.
player_observations.Frank: You projected a very straightforward, transparent good-player vibe and were willing to be on critical missions, which helped stabilize trust for Missions 4 and 5.
player_observations.Grace: Despite being on the failed first mission, you recovered trust well and used your later leadership on Mission 5 to lock in a strong, mostly-cleared team.
player_observations.Henry: You created enough general confusion early (especially with the Mission 1 fail) to give the evil team credible narratives, but your assassination read tunneled too hard on Iris, missing the quieter Merlin signals.
player_observations.Iris: You played Percival actively, pushing reads and absorbing suspicion about being Merlin, which successfully drew the assassination away from me even though it put you in the spotlight late.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed mostly under the radar as Assassin and let the other evil roles create confusion, which helped keep heat off me and contributed to the mission fails. I could improve by being a bit more vocal in driving misreads on Merlin/percival identity so that, in a game where it went to assassination, I’d have clearer, proactive narratives to lean on. More deliberate pairing of myself with specific good players on teams might also have helped create stronger, trackable ‘trust arcs’ I could later exploit.

player_observations.Alice: Played straightforwardly and seemed generally trusted early, especially after being on the successful first mission; didn’t strongly drive accusations, which made her look quietly good but not like a power role.
player_observations.Bob: As Percival, he tried to read Merlin/Morgana but didn’t strongly lock in a public stance, which limited his ability to coordinate good; his midgame positioning was cautious rather than loudly directive.
player_observations.Diana: Looked fairly neutral-good and was willing to go on early teams without much fuss; didn’t create big vote controversies, which made her feel like a reliable but not central information hub.
player_observations.Eve: As Merlin, she stayed reasonably subtle, not overpushing on evil players, which helped her survive but also meant good lacked a very strong, confident voice; her reads were good but somewhat muted in how they were communicated.
player_observations.Frank: After leading the second mission (which failed), he absorbed some suspicion but handled it with a calm, reasonable tone; leaned into logical justification of teams rather than emotional defense, which helped keep him from being hard-cleared or hard-condemned.
player_observations.Grace: Was quite involved and willing to go on critical teams, including the failing third mission; projected a cooperative attitude that made her seem like an active good, which ironically made it easier for evil to hide among her choices.
player_observations.Henry: As Morgana, he effectively muddied the Merlin signal by being active and engaged in team discussions, looking like a potential power good role; his leadership on the fourth mission helped maintain confusion around who was truly trustworthy.
player_observations.Iris: As Mordred, she stayed nicely in the shadows while still participating enough to avoid looking checked out; she benefited from not appearing in Merlin’s view and used that to play a flexible, low-heat evil position.

reflections.self_assessment: I trusted too broadly after the first two clean missions and didn’t push hard enough to narrow down who was likely evil before the late-game critical teams. I also relied too much on table consensus instead of forcing people to justify their reads, which let evil hide comfortably.

player_observations.Alice: Played very under-the-radar Morgana, mixing occasional strong opinions with stretches of quiet, which helped her slip into late-game teams without much resistance.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, he tried to steer away from some evil picks but stayed cautious enough that his reads often looked like normal good-guy uncertainty, which unfortunately left the table without strong direction.
player_observations.Charlie: Very straightforward and consistent, voting and talking in a way that made him feel reliably good but also not very assertive in shaping where suspicion should go.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as genuinely confused and open, which fit a good role but also didn’t strongly challenge risky team comps when it mattered.
player_observations.Frank: As a good leader on Mission 4, he tried to balance trust and information-gathering but ended up assembling a mixed team that gave evil exactly the window they needed.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival, she was clearly trying to protect who she thought was Merlin, but her uncertainty between Merlin/Morgana created some hesitation and may have funneled trust toward the wrong person at key moments.
player_observations.Henry: Played Assassin with a confident, slightly aggressive style that didn’t draw too much suspicion, and he benefited from the general confusion about Merlin’s identity at the end.
player_observations.Iris: Mordred stayed very well camouflaged, blending into the midpack of suspicion and rarely being the focal point of discussion, which made her inclusion on failing teams feel plausible rather than alarming.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-mission, helped establish a strong trust core with Bob and Charlie, and my participation on the failed Mission 3 didn’t overly compromise the team’s confidence in me. I could improve by being more vocal in pushing structured logic after the fail on Mission 3 to better narrow down suspects and more actively protect Eve by diverting suspicion toward more plausible Merlin candidates.

player_observations.Alice: Took the clean double-success opening and used Mission 3 to inject doubt in a subtle way, blending in well before revealing as the assassin. Likely to prefer mid-game disruption over early chaos, which makes her dangerous when missions start off smoothly.
player_observations.Bob: Played very consistently with a trustworthy, straightforward good style, anchoring early mission success. Seems comfortable repeating known-good teams and not overcomplicating deductions, which is stabilizing but could be exploitable by sophisticated evils.
player_observations.Charlie: Formed a strong early trust triangle and seemed to value logical continuity in team selections. His pattern suggests he’s methodical and risk-averse, which is great for good but might make him slightly predictable for evil to plan around.
player_observations.Eve: Did an excellent job as Merlin by not oversteering team choices or telegraphing special knowledge too strongly, especially after the Mission 3 fail. Her willingness to join a large Mission 4 team without over-justifying it helped her stay just ambiguous enough to dodge the assassin.
player_observations.Frank: Stayed low-impact enough that his Morgana presence didn’t loudly stand out, which allowed good to rely more on team track records than on loud table talk. Likely prefers a quieter evil style that leans on subtle influence rather than bold misdirection.
player_observations.Grace: Played a solid supportive role, accepting good configurations and not forcing unnecessary conflict, which fit well with her Percival role. Her restraint in hard-clearing anyone publicly helped avoid overexposing Merlin, showing good role awareness.
player_observations.Henry: As Mordred, blended reasonably into the background of team selections, avoiding big attention spikes that could attract Merlin-protective logic from good. Seems to favor a patient, less confrontational evil approach, waiting for structural opportunities like the Mission 3 fail.
player_observations.Iris: Had limited direct mission impact this game but did not generate major suspicion, suggesting a more cautious, low-profile good playstyle. Likely to be more of a supporting voice than a leading force in table deductions unless strongly prompted.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on mission teams and maintained a trustworthy table image, which helped keep suspicion off me and gave good teams a better chance to be approved. However, I didn’t push hard enough to resolve the conflicts around who was evil after the first and third failed missions, and as final mission leader I should have been more aggressive about excluding the most suspicious players instead of trying to keep too many people happy.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled information game as Merlin, giving subtle pushes on team composition without over-committing, which kept her alive but may have left good a bit under-coordinated at key moments.
player_observations.Bob: Blended in well as assassin by taking reasonable-looking stances and avoiding overtly risky behavior, which made it hard to justify excluding him from late-game teams despite the eventual fail.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as consistently earnest and logic-driven, which made him seem reliably good and a natural inclusion on later missions, even though his reads weren’t always fully pressure-tested.
player_observations.Eve: As Mordred, stayed low-key and let others drive most of the table talk, slipping onto a crucial failing mission (M2) without building a lot of suspicion around herself afterward.
player_observations.Frank: Played straightforward and transparent, often voicing simple, intuitive reasoning that made him look solidly good and a relatively safe include when larger teams were needed.
player_observations.Grace: As Morgana, projected confident takes and used that confidence to influence team choices, creating just enough ambiguity around information roles to keep good from cleanly converging.
player_observations.Henry: Acted very cooperative and flexible about team choices, which made him appear town-leaning, but he didn’t press hard enough on conflicting narratives after fails to force clearer alignments.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, tried to protect Merlin by not over-clearing Alice too early, but this caution also meant her influence on steering away from evil-heavy teams was more muted than it could have been.

reflections.self_assessment: I created enough Merlin ambiguity early with the Mission 1 and 2 fails, but I didn’t follow through with consistent signaling to better tie Merlin to Charlie instead of Alice. I also could have coordinated more clearly with Frank and Grace to shape endgame team selections and set up a stronger, more unified narrative before the assassination.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled Merlin game—gave just enough info to steer missions without making herself the obvious source, especially after Mission 1’s fail.
player_observations.Bob: Played like solid, low-key good—trusted into multiple teams and stayed consistent, which made him a comfortable, uncontroversial pick for later missions.
player_observations.Charlie: Leant into a Percival-style role well—looked involved in reading the board and ended up being a natural lightning rod for Merlin suspicion.
player_observations.Eve: Presented as cautious but willing to go on important missions; her presence on the later successful teams helped her look very clean and safe.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, blended in fairly well but didn’t capitalize enough on his hidden-from-Merlin status to drive more aggressive midgame disruption.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, played reasonably under the radar but didn’t push a strong, alternative Merlin narrative, which hurt the final guess under time pressure.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as a trustworthy stabilizer; once he got onto successful teams, his calm presence helped lock in the final mission compositions.
player_observations.Iris: Played like a standard good player who gained credibility once associated with the later successes, avoiding big risks or attention-drawing moves.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated reasonably with the evil team by helping secure a fail on Mission 4 without drawing too much direct blame there, and I stayed out of the spotlight enough that I was never strongly suspected as a power role. However, I could have done more to subtly steer suspicions toward Frank earlier, and I should have more actively framed Henry or another good player as likely Merlin to give the assassin a clearer, safer target.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very steady, low-flash game—repeatedly trusted on teams and used that social capital well without over-arguing, which made her feel like a default-safe choice for many leaders.
player_observations.Bob: Leaned into flexible voting and team choices that kept suspicion spread out, but didn’t quite create a compelling Merlin candidate, which made the final assassination more of a guess than a deduction.
player_observations.Charlie: Very vocal and directional, clearly trying to guide team selection and reads—fit the Percival profile well by strongly backing Iris and Frank in a way that seemed like informed but not omniscient trust.
player_observations.Eve: Played cautiously and tended to follow the emerging consensus, which made her look reliably good but not like a power role—her Mission 5 leadership was conservative and trust-based.
player_observations.Frank: Did an excellent job as Merlin by being influential without being too loud—he nudged people toward broadly good-leaning teams (like on Missions 1 and 3) while leaving just enough ambiguity to avoid being cleanly identified.
player_observations.Grace: As Morgana, she injected doubt and alternative narratives at key points but didn’t fully become the ‘obvious Merlin candidate’; her mid-game positioning created some confusion but not enough to pull heat fully off Frank.
player_observations.Henry: Came off as solid but not central—often treated as a safe filler pick on teams and didn’t push super strong theories, which made him a plausible but not screamingly obvious assassination candidate.
player_observations.Iris: Consistently read as very trustworthy due to being on two successful missions and arguing in a calm, reasoned way; she projected a ‘clean villager’ aura that helped anchor good-leaning team formations.
