reflections.self_assessment: I trusted the wrong people too easily, especially after Mission 1, and didn’t push hard enough to interrogate the logic behind team choices and voting patterns. I also failed to clearly coordinate with other apparent good players to consolidate suspicion on Charlie and Grace once Mission 3 double-failed. Next time, I should be more vocal about my reasoning and track voting histories more rigorously instead of relying on gut reads.

player_observations.Alice: You played a very straightforward, good-leaning game and seemed genuinely puzzled by the early fails, which made you look authentic but also made it harder for you to sway others. Your inclusion on early failing missions didn’t match your behavior, which suggests you might not be fully leveraging table talk to separate yourself from evil setups.
player_observations.Bob: You were a very quiet Merlin, which kept you safe but made it harder for good to coordinate around your reads. Your subtle nudges on some team choices were there, but they weren’t strong or consistent enough to clearly guide us away from the stacked evil teams.
player_observations.Charlie: You played a bold Mordred, leaning into active leadership and confidently proposing teams that included multiple evil players. Your willingness to sit on a double-fail team (Mission 3) while staying composed afterwards helped keep suspicion diffuse instead of squarely on you.
player_observations.Eve: You came off as sincerely good and somewhat cautious, which made you a stabilizing presence but also meant you weren’t aggressively driving the table’s logic. Your voting felt principled, yet you didn’t push hard enough to challenge the assumptions behind the early mission compositions.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, you seemed to be juggling conflicting Merlin signals and never fully committed to strongly town-reading Bob or distrusting Grace, which let evil hide in that confusion. Your table presence was thoughtful but a bit reactive, and a more decisive stance on the Merlin/Morgana read could have shifted how we built later teams.
player_observations.Grace: You were an extremely convincing Morgana, projecting a calm, analytical tone that mimicked a careful Merlin and drew trust from several of us. Your willingness to be on the first failing mission without over-explaining it later helped maintain the illusion that you were just an unlucky but sincere good player.
player_observations.Henry: As Assassin, you played assertively in leadership and didn’t shy away from putting risky teams forward, which advanced evil’s agenda while not looking overly opportunistic. Your confident posture after mission fails made it harder to pin you as the consistent common denominator behind bad outcomes.
player_observations.Iris: You felt clearly good-leaning in discussion but didn’t assert your reads strongly enough to influence the mission selection meta. Your willingness to go along with more dominant voices meant your good instincts had less impact than they could have if you’d pushed your suspicions more forcefully.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-good in my voting and team approvals, and I adapted reasonably well after the disastrous Mission 3 by trusting Charlie’s reads and pushing for safer late-game teams. I could improve by being more vocal earlier with structured reasoning about who seemed coordinated on the failed missions, instead of mostly following others’ logic in the middle of the game.

player_observations.Alice: You projected a very trustworthy, steady-good vibe, but the Mission 2 fail on your team made you look suspicious for a while and you handled that pressure calmly without over-defensiveness.
player_observations.Bob: You played a low-key, reactive evil game, blending in by not over-pushing narratives, which made it hard to pin you until the pattern of failed missions started to narrow things down.
player_observations.Charlie: You were subtly assertive and generally accurate in your reads, especially in the late game, and your leadership on Missions 4 and 5 felt purposeful without being so obvious that it got you assassinated.
player_observations.Eve: You leaned into a confident, talkative style that created early trust, but the heavy fail on Mission 3 made your earlier certainty look more orchestrated than organic.
player_observations.Frank: You came across as flexible and pragmatic in team discussions, tending to go along with reasoned arguments and helping stabilize trust in the late game missions you were on.
player_observations.Grace: You had a quiet but solid presence, with your clean Mission 1 leadership giving early structure to the good team’s trust network and not drawing unnecessary suspicion later on.
player_observations.Henry: You were very active in shaping table talk and trying to direct team compositions, which was helpful for good overall, though some of your strong stances around the middle missions created mixed signals for trust.
player_observations.Iris: You played an aggressive and bold evil game, especially on Mission 3, leveraging earlier trust to enable a big fail that temporarily threw good into confusion.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated effectively with the rest of the evil team, especially by keeping Mission 2 clean and then pushing the same team on Mission 3 to build trust before flipping it, which helped create confusion around who the real threats were. I could have done a better job subtly shading Bob and protecting Frank and Eve from suspicion earlier, as Merlin and Assassin alignment was a bit clearer than ideal by the endgame.

player_observations.Alice: Alice was willing to go on multiple critical teams and seemed comfortable trusting early mission structures, which made her look reliably good but also somewhat influenceable by stronger table voices.
player_observations.Bob: Bob played a careful Merlin, generally avoiding overt pushes but clearly nudging teams toward more good-heavy compositions, though at times his caution made his reads less impactful than they could have been.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie appeared to prefer logical, consistency-based reasoning and was willing to reuse team templates once they had passed, which made him look stable but also a bit predictable in team selections.
player_observations.Eve: Eve blended in well as evil by not over-controlling discussion and letting others drive team logic, contributing just enough to appear cooperative while preserving flexibility for the final assassination.
player_observations.Frank: Frank played a low-key Mordred, staying out of the direct spotlight and avoiding sharp accusations, which helped him remain off Merlin’s top suspicion list and made him a relatively safe include on early teams.
player_observations.Grace: Grace showed a tendency to take early mission results at face value and appeared to trust social tone and confidence, which made her more persuadable when strong personalities framed the narrative.
player_observations.Henry: Henry seemed cautious and somewhat reactive, often following the emerging consensus on team composition rather than pushing his own agenda, which kept him looking good but limited his influence over the table.
player_observations.Iris: Iris, as Percival, clearly tried to track Merlin through vote patterns and subtle guidance, but her reads on the Merlin/Morgana pair were not fully locked in, which led to some hesitation in late-game trust decisions.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-good in my team choices and voting, especially in the later missions, and helped stabilize trust around the Mission 4 and 5 teams. I could have been more vocal about my reasoning earlier in the game, particularly after Mission 2, to better shape suspicion on Alice and Eve and protect Charlie and Iris more explicitly without outing Merlin.

player_observations.Alice: You blended in well early and leveraged the success of Mission 2 to avoid heat, but the double-fail on Mission 3 made your position much shakier; you tend to rely on strong mid-game swings rather than subtle long-term framing.
player_observations.Bob: You played a very quiet, solid-good style, generally aligning with safe teams and not overpushing your reads; this made you trustworthy but also somewhat easier for evil to ignore.
player_observations.Charlie: Your Merlin play was subtle, nudging suspicion toward the right people without making any loud accusations; you were cautious enough that the assassin couldn’t confidently lock on to you.
player_observations.Eve: You played an assertive evil game by participating in the pivotal failing Mission 3, but the aggression there made you more exposed; your style seems to favor bold, high-impact moves over low-key deception.
player_observations.Frank: You were a strong anchor for good, especially by leading and backing clean teams on Missions 4 and 5; your decisions were consistent and gave the table a stable reference point.
player_observations.Grace: You started a bit uncertain after being on the failed Mission 1 team, but you recovered well and ended up leading crucial successful missions; your willingness to trust evolving information improved as the game went on.
player_observations.Henry: You played an active, misleading early game as assassin, especially with that failed Mission 1, but your later positioning didn’t quite translate into a confident Merlin guess; you seem comfortable taking early risks to create noise.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, you did a good job not over-clearing anyone publicly while still subtly defending the right people; your endgame support for the final mission teams helped confirm a strong good bloc without exposing Merlin.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed generally consistent with a good-aligned voting pattern and backed reasonable teams early, which helped avoid drawing suspicion to myself. However, I didn’t push hard enough to interrogate the Mission 2 and 3 team compositions, and I relied too much on others’ reads instead of building and defending my own clear worldviews.

player_observations.Alice: Played a fairly straightforward good game and was willing to be on early teams, which made her look naturally towny but also somewhat passive in shaping later mission logic.
player_observations.Bob: As Percival, he seemed cautious and a bit conflicted, likely struggling to distinguish Merlin from Morgana, and his uncertainty weakened good’s ability to converge on a strong core.
player_observations.Charlie: As Assassin, he blended in well by not overreaching and allowed others to drive discussion, which helped him avoid standing out as a major suspect.
player_observations.Eve: As Merlin, she was subtly nudging away from certain bad configurations without being too obvious, though her guidance wasn’t strong enough to prevent evil from steering key missions.
player_observations.Frank: Generally looked cooperative and trustworthy, but his leadership on Mission 2 ended up including evil, and he didn’t do enough afterward to re-evaluate and loudly correct course.
player_observations.Grace: Played like a solid, reasonable good player, but her Mission 3 team choice (which double-failed) suggested she trusted the wrong people or over-weighted limited signals.
player_observations.Henry: As Morgana, he leveraged a convincing good persona and benefited from Percival’s confusion, using that ambiguity to get himself and other evils onto critical missions.
player_observations.Iris: As Mordred, she stayed low-profile and let others front the arguments, which made her hard to pin down and allowed her to slip onto an all-evil mission without attracting much suspicion.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed fairly consistent with my voting and team choices, which helped maintain a generally good-aligned image and avoided creating chaos. However, I should have pressed harder on the implications of Mission 3’s single fail and then re-evaluated trust in Alice going into Mission 4 and 5, as I didn’t narrow down the evil team quickly enough.

player_observations.Alice: Played very conservatively early, avoiding suspicion by not appearing on failing teams until late; used her presence on the big 5-player Mission 4 and 5 to deliver decisive fails while still blending into the logic of common team constructions.
player_observations.Bob: Balanced information and subtlety well as Merlin, joining critical missions (like Mission 4) without becoming an obvious focal point of suspicion; seemed to nudge trust patterns without overtly hard-pushing accusations.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a straightforward, low-drama good style, accepting early team proposals and not overcomplicating the read landscape; didn’t generate much suspicion but also didn’t strongly steer the table away from evil.
player_observations.Diana: Looked very towny by leading a successful Mission 2 and then appearing again on my Mission 3 team that only had a single fail; projected reliability, which made it easier for evil to hide alongside her.
player_observations.Frank: As a leader on the crucial 5-player Mission 4, built a team that felt reasonably logical but unfortunately centered around existing trust patterns that included Alice; seemed to prefer constructing broadly acceptable teams rather than hard-pushing niche reads.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival, appeared to trust Bob strongly enough to keep him in contention but not so strongly that it screamed role-knowledge; on the final mission, accepted a risky mix (including Alice and Henry) that looked like a compromise between social reads and table pressure.
player_observations.Henry: Stayed under the radar most of the game, then capitalized late by joining the final mission and dropping a fail alongside Alice; generally avoided moves that would have made him a standout suspect before Mission 5.
player_observations.Iris: Took advantage of being on my Mission 3 team to slip in a single fail that created ambiguity without overexposing herself; her presence there created confusion between multiple possible suspects and set up later evil wins.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed low-key enough that the assassin was pulled toward Diana, while still nudging teams in the right direction, especially on Mission 4 where I backed a fully clean team. I could improve by more systematically masking my support for known-goods earlier in the game, so my late-game confidence spike is less noticeable.

player_observations.Alice: Willing to fail late rather than early, which made you look more cautious and less obvious as the assassin; you blended well on the first two missions.
player_observations.Bob: Consistent, straightforward team choices and voting patterns that felt very ‘by the book’ good, which made you trustworthy pretty early on.
player_observations.Charlie: Played in a logically open way, asking reasonable questions and building trust gradually; your willingness to repeat similar cores helped confirm you as good.
player_observations.Diana: You looked like a strong, confident good leader, which unfortunately also made you an appealing Merlin target; your involvement in the failed mission created just enough ambiguity to misdirect the assassin.
player_observations.Frank: Stayed relatively quiet and tried to ride along with consensus, a classic subtle-evil approach that avoided drawing big suspicion but also didn’t strongly drive the narrative.
player_observations.Grace: Your behavior matched a cautious information-role: you defended some players without overcommitting and helped stabilize team choices, hinting at Percival without fully outing yourself.
player_observations.Henry: You remained in the background and avoided critical leadership spots, which kept you off the radar but also limited your ability to steer suspicion away from your teammates.
player_observations.Iris: Low-impact, low-controversy presence: you didn’t push hard theories, which helped you avoid suspicion but also meant you weren’t a major driver of table reads.

reflections.self_assessment: I timed my single fail on Mission 2 well, creating doubt without overexposing myself, and then stayed off later teams so suspicion could diffuse to others. I could have been more active in shaping the narrative and pushing specific accusations, rather than relying mostly on quiet ambiguity and the chaos created by Merlin and Percival’s reads.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously but her mission choices and reads were generally accurate, especially early; her alignment sense showed, even if she couldn’t quite lock down the evil team in time.
player_observations.Bob: Balanced restraint and aggression well as Assassin, passing Mission 4 to maintain trust and then striking on Mission 5; he was comfortable sitting in the spotlight without drawing too much suspicion.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as straightforward and fairly transparent, often trusting mission results at face value and not overcomplicating the logic, which made him seem consistently good-aligned.
player_observations.Diana: Played in a very team-oriented and cooperative way, which helped her look reliably good; she seemed to rely heavily on mission outcomes and table consensus when making decisions.
player_observations.Frank: Stayed relatively low-key and safe, not forcing big debates but also not doing anything particularly risky; this made him hard to read but also less influential on the final direction.
player_observations.Grace: Took on a more active, talkative, Merlin-like posture as Morgana, and her participation on the failing Mission 3 was disguised well by her confident good-lean tone.
player_observations.Henry: Appeared methodical and somewhat cautious, often deferring to perceived stronger info-holders rather than driving his own bold theories, which helped keep him out of the main suspicion lines.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, she clearly tried to shield who she thought was Merlin and guide teams subtly, but the split signal between Merlin and Morgana seemed to keep her a bit tentative at key moments.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-good with my voting and mission behavior, especially on Missions 3–5, which helped build trust and made it harder for evil to pin Merlin accurately. I could improve by being more vocal about my suspicions earlier, particularly after the early fails, to help coordinate good’s deductions and pressure the suspected evil players more effectively.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very subtle Merlin game—she nudged teams in the right direction without over-defending specific players, which kept suspicion off her enough to survive the assassination. Her early inclusion on Mission 1 despite the fail later didn’t draw much heat, which shows good social positioning.
player_observations.Bob: Consistently looked like a solid, reliable good player through his repeated inclusion on later successful teams. His willingness to go on multiple missions without causing fails made him a natural core pick in the mid-to-late game.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, he did a good job of not over-clearing Merlin publicly, instead blending into the general good information flow. His presence on both an early fail and later successes made his alignment ambiguous but ultimately helpful once the team stabilized.
player_observations.Diana: Managed to get a fail on Mission 2 while keeping suspicion somewhat spread out, showing careful timing and risk management as evil. However, the trajectory of later clean missions steadily eroded trust in her earlier choices and team proposals.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he positioned himself reasonably well by leading a successful Mission 4, which helped mask his earlier evil alignment. Still, that success also forced evil into a more passive role later, reducing his ability to introduce new doubt.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, she stayed just detached enough from the core successful teams that she had to guess Merlin from incomplete signals, which contributed to the mis-assassination. Her read on late-game behavior over-weighted my apparent influence compared to Alice’s quieter guidance.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as very trustworthy once he started appearing on clean missions and then leading the final successful team. His stable, low-drama style made him a comfortable anchor for the endgame good teams.
player_observations.Iris: Joined the successful mid- and late-game teams without generating much controversy, which reinforced her image as a safe inclusion. Her low-key presence helped good by not introducing unnecessary chaos or suspicion when stability was most important.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-good in my voting and helped push through a strong final team, which contributed directly to the win. I could have been more vocal in sharing structured reasoning and reads earlier, which might have put additional pressure on the evil team and made the final missions less tense.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to be trusted early due to being on multiple successful missions, and maintained a stable, low-drama presence that made her look reliably good.
player_observations.Bob: Played a subtle evil game by blending into early discussion and taking a calculated risk on Mission 2, but didn’t generate quite enough towncred to avoid late suspicion.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as methodical and reasoning-focused, consistently trying to frame missions and votes in a logical way that fit well with a Percival mindset.
player_observations.Diana: Used her leader position to push a mixed team that looked plausible, balancing aggression with just enough caution to keep herself from seeming blatantly evil.
player_observations.Frank: Did an excellent job as Merlin by guiding team selections toward good-heavy lineups without overexplaining, staying helpful but not so accurate as to be obviously targetable.
player_observations.Grace: Leaned into a confident and slightly assertive style that fit Morgana well, creating ambiguity around information and making it harder to cleanly separate her from Merlin candidates.
player_observations.Henry: Played a very natural, low-key good game; his inclusion on both a failed and a successful team made him a believable but ultimately misleading assassination target.
player_observations.Iris: Looked consistently good by being on key successful missions and keeping a cooperative, non-flashy profile that didn’t attract much suspicion or assassination pressure.

reflections.self_assessment: I should have pushed much harder on scrutinizing Mission 1’s fail and narrowing suspicion onto Henry instead of letting that team composition slide socially. I also didn’t do enough to publicly structure the logic after Mission 2 and 3 fails, which let evil control the narrative; next time I’ll speak up earlier with clearer reasoning and push for tighter, evidence-based team building.

player_observations.Alice: Played in a straightforward, sincere way that made her seem generically good but not strongly cleared, which let evil hide behind her. She didn’t overassert herself, so her presence on failed missions was easy to mentally handwave instead of properly analyzing.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, he played cautiously and didn’t hard-push specific suspects, which kept him safe but also left the good team without a strong, coordinated direction. His soft nudges were there, but subtle enough that they were easy to ignore in the chaos of repeated mission fails.
player_observations.Charlie: Very composed and persuasive as Mordred, especially in Mission 3 where he anchored a disastrous team while sounding reasonable. He framed arguments in a calm, logical tone that made his proposals feel safe even when they clearly shouldn’t have been after back-to-back fails.
player_observations.Diana: Seemed quietly reasonable and not overly performative, which made her feel like a safe, low-drama pick. Because she didn’t push sharp accusations, she faded into the background a bit and didn’t strongly influence team direction for good or evil.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he didn’t clearly signal strong Merlin reads in a way that I could reliably follow, which made coordination between good power roles weaker. His play felt like standard good rather than a protective, guiding presence for Merlin’s information.
player_observations.Grace: As Morgana, she did a strong job blending in as a potentially insightful good player and used that to get on critical teams. Her social confidence helped normalize risky lineups, especially early, when we should have been much more skeptical after the first fail.
player_observations.Henry: As Assassin, he played Mission 1 very smoothly and didn’t attract the level of suspicion that a first-mission fail deserved. He managed to stay socially plausible across multiple fails, which means he balanced just enough talk to seem engaged without overexplaining.
player_observations.Iris: Came across as genuinely good and somewhat trusting, which made her a useful barometer of where the general table sentiment was going. She didn’t strongly drive team selection meta, but her agreement or hesitation subtly reinforced which narratives gained traction.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the evil team on Mission 3, helping create strong suspicion around Alice and Iris while keeping my own role ambiguous early. I could have done more in the late game to steer suspicion toward Charlie instead of letting Merlin remain relatively under the radar, especially by pushing harder, earlier, on alternative Merlin candidates.

player_observations.Alice: Played very proactively and was often centered in teams, but managed to stay just suspicious enough after Mission 3 that evil could plausibly push her as Merlin or evil without it seeming forced.
player_observations.Bob: Took bold risks as Assassin, leaning into the heavy suspicion around Alice and committing hard to that narrative in the endgame rather than hedging between multiple Merlin candidates.
player_observations.Charlie: Stayed calm and relatively low-key for a Merlin, influencing team selection without loudly driving accusations, which helped them slide past the final assassination guess.
player_observations.Diana: Played a steady, low-drama good role, going along with reasonable team choices and not overextending with accusations, which made her feel reliably good but not Merlin-like.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as very team- and logic-focused, especially on the later missions, and helped solidify trust in the Mission 4 and 5 teams without drawing too much spotlight.
player_observations.Grace: Started the game with a successful Mission 1 team and then largely blended into the background later, which reduced suspicion and made her an easy inclusion on the final good-leaning teams.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, did a good job protecting Merlin by keeping suspicion spread between visible power roles and participating in arguments in a way that didn’t overly shield Charlie.
player_observations.Iris: As Mordred, took on a very aggressive role in Mission 3 with multiple fails on the team, which generated chaos but also drew heat that good players were eventually able to parse and work around.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively low-profile while letting other evil roles (especially Diana and Frank) take on more visible risk, which helped keep suspicion off me going into the later missions and preserved my assassination threat. I could improve by being more proactive in shaping table narratives and pushing specific suspicions earlier, so that if the game had gone to an assassination decision, I’d have had clearer, more socially justified targets.

player_observations.Alice: Played in a straightforward, logic-driven way that made her look consistently villager-like, but she didn’t push hard enough to reframe suspicions when evil narratives gained traction.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, he was cautious rather than loud, nudging team compositions instead of hard-clearing or hard-accusing, which made him harder to nail down as a power role but also less influential on the mission outcomes.
player_observations.Charlie: Showed a balanced, cooperative style—asked the right questions and seemed to care about team structure—but didn’t leave very strong signature ‘good’ footprints, which made him blend into the middle of the pack.
player_observations.Diana: As Morgana, she leaned into looking like a strong, info-driven good player, which helped create ambiguity for Percival and gave evil a credible voice when missions were being debated.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he was comfortable taking early risk (like going on the first mission) while not overtalking, which kept his alignment obscured and let others carry most of the social weight.
player_observations.Grace: Her participation on the first failed mission made her a convenient suspicion sink; after that, she seemed somewhat reactive, defending herself more than driving new lines of inquiry.
player_observations.Henry: Played a solid but somewhat understated good game, often following the emerging consensus rather than forcefully challenging team proposals, which reduced his impact on steering critical mission choices.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, she clearly tried to track Merlin vs. Morgana but didn’t fully translate that into aggressive team curation; her leadership on Mission 4 showed some trust decisions that ultimately benefited evil.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated the double-fail on Mission 3 cleanly and stayed generally under the radar as a hard-confirmed evil without drawing immediate late-game suspicion. However, I could have done more to subtly steer the assassin away from Iris and toward Charlie by planting doubt earlier and reinforcing narratives that framed Charlie’s behavior as ‘cautious good’ rather than confidently insightful.

player_observations.Alice: Played an assertive, proactive evil game, volunteering for key missions and using social confidence to appear like a central information hub, which helped mask coordinated fails. Tended to lean into strong, decisive table-talk that discouraged others from deeply re-questioning early assumptions.
player_observations.Bob: Played a relatively quiet, low-conflict good role, often going along with emerging consensuses rather than driving team compositions. This made them appear fairly trustworthy but also limited their impact on late-game strategic pivots.
player_observations.Charlie: As Merlin, balanced giving just enough direction to influence teams without over-extending; their early involvement in the first mission and subsequent reads were subtly consistent with hidden info. They managed their tone well—measured and reasonable—so their guidance felt organic rather than forced.
player_observations.Diana: Showed a steady, methodical good playstyle, often focusing on logical consistency and mission results over emotional reads. Their inclusion on multiple successful teams increased their perceived reliability and made them a stabilizing presence in team discussions.
player_observations.Frank: Adopted a pragmatic, results-oriented approach, willing to repeat successful team structures and avoid unnecessary risk. Their leadership on Mission 4 with a clean result reinforced a trustworthy image and helped lock in a good-favored team configuration.
player_observations.Grace: Played a socially central and confident good role, especially by the time of Mission 5, where they used prior success patterns to justify team choices. Their willingness to take responsibility for the final team helped solidify a narrative that strongly favored good’s known or suspected allies.
player_observations.Henry: As Assassin, leaned into early aggression with the failed first mission, which created some initial chaos but didn’t fully transition into a precise Merlin read later. The final shot on Iris suggests they overweighted visible influence and apparent caution, underestimating Charlie’s subtler guiding touches.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, projected a cautious but engaged presence, often asking framing questions rather than dictating teams, which made them look like a thoughtful good trying to piece things together. Their behavior successfully mimicked a plausible Merlin profile, drawing the assassin’s attention and protecting Charlie.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly avoided hard-clearing the wrong people and stayed reasonably subtle about my reads, but I clearly failed to guide missions away from the consolidated evil bloc, especially by Mission 3. I need to improve at signaling stronger suspicion on key evil players without outing myself, and at shaping team compositions more assertively when mission results start to give solid info.

player_observations.Alice: Played a quiet, low-key good game that didn’t draw much suspicion, especially after being on the successful first mission.
player_observations.Bob: As Percival, seemed cautious and somewhat conservative in pushing reads, likely trying not to reveal who he thought Merlin was, but this also made his information less impactful.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-mission and avoided raising suspicion, which helped keep trust in me high throughout the game. However, I didn’t push hard enough on deduction or publicly challenge shaky assumptions about who was evil, especially after Mission 3 failed, and I should have been more vocal in narrowing down evil candidates.

player_observations.Charlie: Played straightforward and low-drama, which made them seem reliably good but also meant they didn’t strongly direct the table when suspicions were fragmented.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as solidly trustworthy, taking part in 2 successful missions and not overtalking her innocence, which helped her avoid suspicion even after being on the failed Mission 3.

player_observations.Iris: Stayed in the background for much of the game, letting others take the social spotlight; this quiet Mordred style made it hard for good to justify excluding her from consideration without strong evidence.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated reasonably well with the evil team by staying mostly low-key and letting others drive team selections, which helped keep suspicion off me for most of the game. However, I didn’t do enough to create plausible Merlin candidates beyond Eve, and I should have been more proactive in muddying the waters for Percival and pushing alternative reads that could have led the assassin away from Eve.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to play cautiously and avoided drawing attention, which helped her survive to the assassin phase without being too heavily suspected. Could perhaps have done more overt misdirection late-game to steer the kill toward a stronger decoy Merlin.
player_observations.Bob: Came across as steady and reliable, and his repeated inclusion on early mission teams built a lot of trust around him. He didn’t overtalk, which made his presence on teams feel safe and uncontroversial.
player_observations.Charlie: Played as a consistent, logic-driven voice who helped stabilize team discussions. Their calm reasoning style made them look reliably good and helped support the success of early missions without seeming flashy or Merlin-like.
player_observations.Diana: Got positioned as a key core member of teams and looked quite trustworthy for most of the game. The failed mission with her on it created some ambiguity, but she still managed to avoid being a strong Merlin candidate in the end.
player_observations.Eve: Did a strong job as Merlin by nudging team choices in the right direction without appearing too controlling. Her subtle influence didn’t flag her as obviously special, which ultimately protected her from the assassin’s guess.
player_observations.Grace: Played a very perceptive, watchful game and often tracked mission compositions and voting patterns closely. As Percival, she seemed careful not to out her information too blatantly, which kept evil from easily identifying who she was.
player_observations.Henry: Stayed relatively under the radar, which as Mordred is valuable since it limits Merlin’s ability to call you out directly with confidence in social reads. Could potentially have applied more pressure in discussions to create confusion about where the evil team was located.
player_observations.Iris: Took a more low-key good role, contributing enough to not look checked out but not dominating conversations. This quieter presence made it harder for evil to get clear reads or exploit her, and she fit into good teams without much objection.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-mission and avoided drawing suspicion as evil, which helped keep trust in me high on later teams. player_observations.Iris: As Percival, she tried to protect Merlin by not over-directing teams, but her cautious style sometimes blurred the distinction between Merlin and Morgana signals.

reflections.self_assessment: I played cautiously as Mordred and helped secure early mission fails, but I didn't translate that into a convincing Merlin read for the assassin, which ultimately cost us the game. I also blended in a bit too well on the late successful missions, failing to create enough doubt or chaos around Alice and Charlie when it mattered.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to be central in early missions and came off very credibly good, which made the late-game suspicion on her plausible enough for the assassin to bite; her willingness to go on mixed teams without over-defending herself helped her look like a realistic Merlin candidate.
player_observations.Bob: Played assassin patiently and let others (especially Morgana/Mordred) drive more of the mission chaos, which helped him stay relatively low-profile when it came time to pick Merlin—but he slightly over-weighted Alice’s influence and under-read Charlie’s quieter, structured contributions.
player_observations.Charlie: As Merlin, he did a nice job of nudging team compositions toward safer groups in Missions 4 and 5 without over-asserting early, keeping his signal subtle enough that evil misfired on the assassination while still rescuing the game after a brutal Mission 3.

player_observations.Iris: As Mordred, she took a bold line by leading Mission 3 and allowing such a heavy fail, which massively scrambled reads and created a lot of noise; the downside was that it eventually pushed the table toward safer, more conservative teams that excluded her from the final missions.

reflections.self_assessment: I blended in reasonably well as Mordred on the early missions, helping create just enough uncertainty around who was evil without drawing heavy suspicion onto myself. player_observations.Alice: Played straightforwardly and seemed to trust early mission structures, which made her look generally towny but also a bit influenceable in team selection dynamics.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, he was cautious rather than aggressively steering, which kept him alive but also allowed evil more room to maneuver on critical missions.
player_observations.Charlie: Approached team choices logically and appeared to rely heavily on mission outcomes and voting history, which made his reasoning transparent and relatively easy to anticipate.
player_observations.Diana: Did a strong job as Morgana, projecting a confident good persona and helping create ambiguity around Merlin’s identity through consistent, reasoned commentary.

player_observations.Henry: Tended to be methodical and a bit conservative in team trust, focusing on previous mission results, which made him slow to fully pivot even when new information suggested alternative narratives.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on messages that supported a good narrative, especially around Missions 2, 4, and 5, and I anchored trust well with Diana, Grace, and Iris by backing stable, low-risk teams. I could improve by being more vocal early about suspicions on Alice and Eve after the double-fail on Mission 3, and by pushing harder to keep Charlie in the discussion as a likely information-holder without exposing them as Merlin.

player_observations.Iris: Played a classic Percival game—protective of who they thought was Merlin and willing to take some heat to keep others safe, especially in late-game team debates; their willingness to be on the critical 4th and 5th mission teams helped cement a trustworthy core despite earlier ambiguity.

reflections.self_assessment: I led a mission that ultimately failed, which means I either trusted the wrong people or didn’t push hard enough to scrutinize the team composition, especially including both Grace and Charlie without stronger reasoning. I could improve by being more vocal about suspicions after each mission result and by tracking voting/teaming patterns more rigorously instead of relying on gut reads.

I could improve by more vocally pushing structured logic earlier, especially after Mission 2 and Mission 3, to narrow down the evil team faster and better protect Merlin through my reads.

player_observations.Alice: You came off very town-leaning early by leading a clean Mission 1 and were a natural focal point for trust, which made you a plausible Merlin target later. Your mid-game involvement stayed measured, though Mission 2’s fail on a team including you made you an ambiguous but still somewhat trusted figure.
player_observations.Bob: You played the assassin quietly enough that you weren’t loudly flagged as evil, but not so convincingly that the final shot landed on Merlin, suggesting your read of the information and table talk could be sharper. Your participation on the heavily failed Mission 3 helped get that sabotage through but also risked overexposure for the evil team.
player_observations.Charlie: You balanced sharing useful suspicions with not over-directing the table, which helped you stay believable but not obvious as Merlin. Your leadership on Mission 4 and then Mission 5 (via influence and trust-building) steered us toward clean teams at crucial moments.
player_observations.Diana: You played a solid, low-drama good game, backing successful teams in the late missions and not overcomplicating the table talk. Your inclusion on Missions 4 and 5 without causing suspicion reinforced you as a reliable, steady presence.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, you leaned into being readable as a potential Merlin, especially around the chaotic Mission 3 fail, but your positioning didn’t fully convince the assassin at the end. Your involvement in both a clean Mission 1 and the disastrous Mission 3 created a mixed record that helped evil for a while but also made you harder to fully clear.
player_observations.Frank: You appeared reliable and cooperative, and your presence on the last two successful missions helped lock in a trustworthy core. Despite being on a failed Mission 2, you managed to keep suspicion relatively low by later aligning with good outcomes and consistent reasoning.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, you did a decent job not making Merlin too obvious, though your involvement in both a failed (Mission 2) and then successful late missions gave you a swingy profile. Your eventual alignment with the correct endgame teams suggested you were reading the Merlin/Morgana signals reasonably well by the end.
player_observations.Iris: You played Mordred in a way that took advantage of the confusion around Mission 3, helping drive a strong multi-fail that really pressured the good team. However, the aggression of that triple-fail also created a big information spike that, in hindsight, made it easier for good to consolidate into safer teams in Missions 4 and 5.

reflections.self_assessment: I trusted the wrong people early, especially after Mission 1, and didn’t push hard enough to clear my name or interrogate why that team failed. I should have focused more on cross-checking team patterns around Diana and Eve, and on reading Merlin signals from Bob instead of treating everyone’s claims and proposals at face value.

player_observations.Alice: Played very straightforwardly and looked consistently good; being on multiple mixed teams without over-defending herself made it harder to find the real evil players around her.
player_observations.Bob: Was cautious and low-key, which fits as Merlin, but the subtlety of his preferences and suspicions made it easy to miss his signals without actively tracking them.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as very reasonable and cooperative, which helped him seem reliably good and made his overlapping teams a useful but underutilized data point.
player_observations.Diana: Blended in well as a core, trustworthy-looking player and repeatedly ended up on critical teams, using that central position to slip a fail into Mission 3 without drawing big blowback.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed relatively under the radar while ending up on the final failing mission, capitalizing on others’ perceived trust networks instead of loudly steering the table herself.
player_observations.Frank: Got early trust from being on the first mission with only one fail and didn’t attract enough follow-up suspicion, which let him fade into the background as an unexamined variable.
player_observations.Henry: Felt like a generally solid, good-leaning voice whose presence on the mixed Mission 2/3 teams complicated reads but didn’t make him stand out as strongly suspicious.
player_observations.Iris: Acted like a central information-holding role, often trying to influence team comps; her trust choices (especially on the last mission) were pivotal but tough to decode from the outside.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-mission and built trust by being on multiple successful teams, especially missions 2, 4, and 5, which helped anchor a good bloc. I could improve by more actively challenging the narrative after Mission 1’s fail and Mission 3’s double-fail, pushing harder to narrow down the evil team earlier instead of mostly following the emerging consensus.

player_observations.Alice: Played aggressively and leaned into trust early by captaining Mission 3, using the double-fail to redirect suspicion onto others rather than herself.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very low-key, stable good game, blending into the background while quietly ending up on the final two clean missions without drawing much suspicion.
player_observations.Charlie: As Merlin, gave strong but not overly loud directional nudges, especially around trusting the Mission 2/4/5 core, while staying just ambiguous enough to avoid being a clean assassination target.
player_observations.Diana: Consistently appeared reasonable and logical, and her repeated presence on successful mission teams reinforced her image as a safe, reliable pick.
player_observations.Eve: Coordinated well with the evil team on Mission 3, taking advantage of the double-fail to create confusion and make the mission’s blame distribution more diffuse.
player_observations.Frank: Played a very clear, trustworthy good role, especially as leader on Mission 4, where he chose a strong, mostly-proven team and stuck to it for the final mission core.
player_observations.Henry: As Assassin, leaned into early credibility by leading Mission 1 and using that initial fail to sow doubt about others, but later struggled to correctly parse the Merlin/Perceval pair and misfired on the final guess.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, projected a confident, central presence and drew a lot of attention, successfully absorbing suspicion and ultimately the assassination shot away from Merlin.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed open to reevaluating reads as new mission results came in and tried to keep my voting consistent with my stated logic, which helped maintain some trust. However, I clearly misread the evil distribution on Missions 2 and 3 and then compounded it by proposing a very risky team on Mission 3 that gave evil too much cover; I need to be more cautious about who I clear early and more vocal about alternative team constructions.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very low-key but consistently trustworthy game, benefiting from being on the successful first mission and not drawing much suspicion afterward.
player_observations.Bob: Classic Percival style: actively engaged, nudging attention toward Eve while trying to keep her safe, though his support of some later teams made his reads look a bit muddled from my perspective.
player_observations.Charlie: Very effective as Assassin, blending in by taking fairly reasonable public stances and not overpushing, which made it hard to pin him as evil even after failed missions.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as straightforward and sincere, and her presence on the first successful mission plus relatively clean table talk helped her avoid serious scrutiny.
player_observations.Eve: Did a strong job as Merlin, subtly steering suspicion toward the real threats without overcommitting, although her caution sometimes made it harder for me to confidently follow her reads.
player_observations.Frank: Looked solidly good for most of the game; his leadership on Mission 2 became a point of confusion, but his tone and reasoning stayed consistently pro-town.
player_observations.Henry: Played Morgana convincingly by mirroring some of Eve’s reasoning and presenting himself as a thoughtful, analytical good player, which made his teams feel safer than they actually were.
player_observations.Iris: Stayed relatively under the radar while still influencing team compositions just enough, using her lower profile as Mordred to avoid becoming a primary suspect even after multiple failed missions.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed well hidden as an assassin, letting the heat fall on others while still helping evil secure the crucial mission fails, especially late in the game. I could improve by more actively shaping table talk and accusations earlier, so that endgame suspicions are directed more predictably toward the wrong targets.

player_observations.Alice: Your Morgana play was subtle; you didn’t over-claim insight, which made the Merlin/Morgana distinction harder for good. You could lean a bit more into confidently pushing narratives to drag more suspicion away from Bob.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin you played cautiously and didn’t hard-clear many players, which kept you alive longer but also left your team with less direction. Your low-key style nearly kept you safe, but a bit more targeted nudging might have helped good avoid stacking evil late.
player_observations.Charlie: You tended to trust early mission compositions and didn’t strongly challenge the developing consensus, which made you seem agreeable but also somewhat passive. A bit more skepticism and vocal reasoning might help you avoid being steered by evil.
player_observations.Diana: You consistently favored ‘safe-looking’ teams and were willing to repeat players from previous missions, which is stabilizing but also exploitable by hidden evil. Adding more structured reasoning about who is cleared vs. tainted could sharpen your impact.
player_observations.Eve: You played a solid, middle-of-the-road good game, neither too loud nor too quiet, which made you hard to read and easy to keep on teams. Pushing harder on who you distrusted and why could have shifted some of the critical later-team discussions.
player_observations.Frank: As a leader on a key mission, you opted for a fairly inclusive, information-rich team, which unfortunately let evil slip in while still looking reasonable. Being a bit more suspicious of players with ambiguous histories might help you build safer late-game teams.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival you seemed genuinely conflicted about the Merlin/Morgana signals, which is good (you weren’t tunneling), but you didn’t fully weaponize your role to protect Merlin. Sharper cross-checking of who pushed or avoided Alice vs. Bob could have given you a clearer read.
player_observations.Iris: Your Mordred play stayed nicely under the radar; you avoided drawing role-based suspicion and helped keep good uncertain about where the fails came from. You could perhaps take more initiative in steering narratives, as your low profile gave you influence but not maximum control.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed mostly under the radar as Mordred and didn't attract strong suspicion, but I also failed to meaningfully steer team selections or discussion away from Merlin. I need to be more proactive in shaping the narrative, pushing subtle suspicion onto non-Merlin players, and coordinating more clearly with my fellow evil roles about where the assassin shot should go.

player_observations.Alice: Played assassin cautiously and waited for more information rather than forcing an early narrative, but could refine endgame logic to weigh Eve’s quiet influence more heavily.
player_observations.Bob: Came across as consistently trustworthy and steady, contributing just enough reasoning without overexplaining, which helped him stay uncontroversial on multiple missions.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a very cooperative, logic-forward style that made them a natural inclusion on teams and helped reinforce trust in the early successful missions.
player_observations.Diana: Looked very mission-focused and straightforward, which made the failed Mission 3 an effective red herring that drew some late suspicion despite her generally clean image.
player_observations.Eve: Did an excellent job as Merlin by guiding team selections subtly and avoiding overtly strong pushes that would reveal her, especially around Mission 4’s composition.
player_observations.Frank: As Morgana, stayed relatively low-key and didn’t overclaim information, but could perhaps lean harder into mimicking Merlin-like guidance to create more confusion for Percival.
player_observations.Grace: Played Percival carefully, following and reinforcing Eve’s leads without making it obvious whom she trusted most, which helped protect Merlin through to the assassin phase.
player_observations.Henry: N/A
player_observations.Iris: Maintained a low-profile good playstyle, not driving major decisions but also not generating much suspicion, which kept the table’s focus on more vocal players.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed generally consistent in my voting and tried to reason from team compositions, but I didn’t push hard enough to lock in a tight circle of trust among confirmed-seeming goods. I also failed to strongly challenge the inclusion of suspicious players on the later missions, especially after Mission 2’s fail gave us useful info I didn’t fully exploit.

player_observations.Alice: Played subtly and cautiously as Merlin; her accusations and preferences were logical but not so strong as to reveal herself, which made it harder for us to clearly follow her without exposing her.
player_observations.Bob: As Assassin, he maintained a fairly reasonable good façade, especially by mixing his teams and not overselling strong reads; his presence on the failed teams ended up looking more like ‘unlucky overlap’ than clearly evil.
player_observations.Charlie: Generally projected a straightforward good vibe and was willing to be on key missions, but didn’t (or couldn’t) decisively steer the table against the evil core despite being on both a success and a fail.
player_observations.Diana: Played like a cooperative good, accepting reasonable-looking teams and not drawing a lot of suspicion, but her involvement on Mission 2’s fail added confusing noise that evil leveraged well.
player_observations.Eve: As Mordred, she leveraged early participation in a failed mission (Mission 2) without becoming the sole focus of blame, spreading suspicion effectively across multiple players instead of herself.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as reliably good and non-flashy, which helped him get onto critical missions; his presence on Mission 4’s success gave that team a cleaner image and indirectly gave evil cover elsewhere.
player_observations.Grace: As Morgana, she mirrored some Merlin-like behavior just enough to blur information reads, keeping ambiguity around who might be the real information holder and helping protect Bob’s endgame.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, she played in a way that didn’t overtly hard-clear Alice as Merlin, which was good for Merlin’s safety but also left the rest of us with too much ambiguity between the info roles.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on good-leaning teams and helped lock in a strong core after Mission 2, which contributed to the clean runs on Missions 3–5. I could have been more vocal in challenging the early trust in Charlie and in pressing harder on the Diana/Frank/Grace triangle after the two early fails, to shorten evil’s window of influence.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very low-key Merlin, letting the evidence from missions speak instead of hard-pushing reads, which helped her avoid the assassin’s attention. She subtly nudged teams away from the worst combinations without overcommitting.
player_observations.Bob: Came across as very consistently villagey, especially by being willing to go on multiple later teams without generating extra suspicion. His presence on the triple-success chain (Missions 3–5) reinforced him as a cornerstone of the good bloc.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, he looked somewhat suspicious early because of Mission 1’s fail and his proximity to evil, but he managed not to over-clear the wrong people. His midgame behavior made him a natural part of the good core once more information emerged.
player_observations.Diana: Did a strong job as Morgana early, especially by getting onto a failing Mission 2 team in a way that didn’t make her instantly obvious afterward. She projected a reasonably trustworthy tone that forced good to spend time untangling her alignment.
player_observations.Eve: Played a very solid, calm good game, and her presence on the clean missions helped anchor trust in the final team compositions. She attracted the assassination shot, which means her table image was convincingly ‘important good’ without being too obviously non-Merlin.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he leveraged hidden information well by blending into team discussions and not being an obvious source of the early fails. Once the clean team pattern emerged, however, he couldn’t reinsert himself without drawing suspicion.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, she created early chaos with the Mission 1 fail while not becoming the primary focus of suspicion afterward. Her final shot on Eve showed she read the good core reasonably well but slightly misjudged who was quietly steering information.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-good in team votes and helped anchor trust on Alice and Iris, which paid off in Mission 1 and the final team. I could have been more vocal in connecting the pattern of failed missions to Diana and Bob sooner, and I might have drawn a bit more suspicion onto myself to help protect Merlin.

player_observations.Alice: Very steady and generally trusted; her early inclusion on multiple teams built a strong core of perceived-good players that shaped most later team compositions.
player_observations.Bob: Played the assassin role aggressively but subtly, using the single fail on Mission 2 to create doubt without over-exposing himself; tried to sit in a semi-trust zone rather than appearing too clean.
player_observations.Charlie: Leaned into the Percival role by strongly backing Frank and often aligning with Iris, pushing a specific narrative of who was trustworthy without over-explaining their reads.
player_observations.Diana: Managed to get on key missions as Mordred, especially Mission 4, and used that fail to create chaos while not loudly directing suspicion, relying more on positioning than open argument.
player_observations.Eve: Played a very straightforward good style; her leadership on Mission 5 was decisive and she was willing to trust the established core instead of overthinking late-game possibilities.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, gave clear but not overly obvious guidance, subtly steering teams away from the worst evil combinations while avoiding hard accusations that would reveal his role.
player_observations.Grace: As Morgana, mirrored Merlin-like confidence at times to muddy the waters for Percival, often chiming in with plausible reads that supported evil-aligned team constructions.
player_observations.Iris: Consistently appeared clean and cooperative; her presence on successful missions and measured table talk made her an anchor for good, especially in justifying the final team.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with Charlie and Grace to get early mission fails without drawing too much suspicion, especially by spreading the fails across different teams. However, I could improve at reading Merlin earlier—Bob’s careful, slightly over-justified reasoning was a clue I only fully appreciated late, and tightening that read faster would make my assassination more precise in future games.

player_observations.Alice: Tends to trust early mission data heavily and sticks to those impressions; once she marks someone as suspicious, she’s slow to fully reconsider.
player_observations.Bob: Plays very cautiously and explains votes in a way that slightly over-defends cleared players, which is a subtle Merlin tell when viewed in hindsight.
player_observations.Charlie: Comfortable taking calculated risks as evil and is willing to put himself on risky teams, relying on social confidence to deflect suspicion afterward.
player_observations.Diana: Votes and team preferences are fairly straightforward and logic-driven, which makes her alignment readable but also makes her a good anchor for good teams when she’s trusted.
player_observations.Eve: Relies a lot on table consensus and social reads; she’s less likely to push hard contrarian takes, which can let stronger voices shape her perceptions.
