player_observations.Iris: Shows good instincts but sometimes lacks conviction in pushing them; she floated correct suspicions without fully following through to reshape the table’s narrative.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably consistent in trusting Charlie and doubting Bob/Eve by the end, and I helped steer Mission 4–5 teams in a good direction after the chaos of Mission 2–3. I could improve by being more vocal and structured about my Percy reads earlier, especially after the single fail on Mission 2, and by challenging the logic behind the Mission 3 team a lot harder.

player_observations.Alice: You projected a very townie, confident presence, and your Mission 4 team was clean and well-constructed, which made you look like a strong info hub (and thus a reasonable assassin target). You did a good job not overreacting to the Mission 2 fail even though you were on it.
player_observations.Bob: You leaned into the chaos on Mission 3 in a way that created a lot of uncertainty and noise, which worked well for you as Assassin. Your social tone was aggressive enough to push suspicion elsewhere without overcommitting to any single narrative.
player_observations.Charlie: You balanced giving direction with not overexposing yourself, especially by backing solid late-game teams without screaming ‘Merlin’. Your reads lined up cleanly with the final good team composition, which made your eventual survival over Alice impressive.
player_observations.Diana: You played a low-drama, stabilizing good role, which helped make the late missions feel safer once you were included. Your willingness to go on back-to-back crucial missions without over-defending yourself made you read quite genuine.
player_observations.Eve: You played a very convincing pseudo-good early on, especially being willing to go on the clean Mission 1 and then the doomed Mission 3, which muddied the waters a lot. Your partnership with Bob in sowing confusion was subtle rather than loud, which is strong for a hidden evil.
player_observations.Frank: You came across as straightforward and pragmatic, especially on the clean Mission 4–5 teams, which helped solidify you as a reliable pick later. Your lack of theatrics made evil pushing on you difficult without looking forced.
player_observations.Grace: Your Mission 1 leadership was quiet but effective, giving good an early success that felt natural rather than staged. Later, you played a more supporting, consensus-building role that helped lock in confidence on the final team rather than trying to re-open old debates.
player_observations.Iris: You did a great job weaponizing the Mission 3 disaster to throw shade broadly, using your Mordred status to stay off Merlin’s radar while still being central to the action. Your earlier willingness to be on mixed teams without looking overly nervous made you a persistent mid-spectrum read instead of an obvious suspect.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed fairly consistent in supporting mission 2’s correct team, which helped confirm some good players, but I didn’t push hard enough to lock in that same core for mission 3. I also should have been more suspicious of Diana after the mission 3 fail and advocated more strongly against the large, mixed mission 4 team that gave evil too much cover.

player_observations.Alice: Appeared generally trustworthy and kept getting picked, which helped good early but also made it easier for evil to hide among familiar names on later missions.
player_observations.Bob: Played Merlin cautiously, not oversteering team choices, which made him look reasonably neutral but may have limited how much he could subtly correct bad team proposals.
player_observations.Charlie: Gravitated toward the successful mission 2 team, which was good, but didn’t fully capitalize on that information to resist repeating or expanding into more suspicious lineups later.
player_observations.Diana: Blended very well as evil by sticking close to previously successful team compositions and only introducing a single fail at a time to avoid drawing attention.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed in the background of team selection yet ended up on the critical failing mission 4, suggesting a low-profile, opportunistic evil style.
player_observations.Frank: Got early access to mission 1, used the single fail to sow doubt without overexposing, and then stayed out of the spotlight afterward, which made him hard to pin down.
player_observations.Grace: Her inclusion on the failed first mission made her look suspicious early, and she didn’t have many later chances to clearly prove her loyalty.
player_observations.Iris: As Percival, she seemed genuinely uncertain between Merlin and Morgana and allowed Diana to stay highly trusted, which was pivotal in giving evil repeated mission access.

reflections.self_assessment: I created early confusion by failing Mission 1 and putting suspicion on Charlie and Grace, but I didn’t properly track how the later mission approvals made Charlie look consistently correct and therefore likely to be Merlin. I tunneled too hard on Iris as Merlin after her clean Mission 2 team and didn’t sufficiently re-evaluate once the good team locked in the same successful team twice at the end.

player_observations.Alice: Played aggressively evil, anchoring the key failing Mission 3 while still staying viable enough that her team proposals weren’t auto-rejected, which helped create mid-game chaos. She leveraged Mordred’s hidden nature well by not over-defending obviously suspicious players.
player_observations.Bob: Played quietly and conservatively, which made him look generically good but not obviously insightful. His inclusion in the final two successful teams suggested he followed the emerging consensus rather than driving it.
player_observations.Charlie: Showed strong mission intuition: being on the first failed mission but then consistently aligning with the successful configurations made him look like someone with extra information in hindsight. He wasn’t overly vocal, but when his implicit preferences matched the eventual good-team core, it should have been a Merlin giveaway.
player_observations.Diana: Looked very reliably good by being on both the failed Mission 3 and later successful missions without appearing to drive any evil agenda. Her consistent presence on late-game good teams helped anchor a trustworthy core for others.
player_observations.Eve: Contributed to the heavy fail on Mission 3 in a way that spread suspicion across multiple players, which is strong Morgana play. However, the lack of strong Merlin-like table control from her made it easier for good to eventually separate her from any Merlin candidates.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as a stabilizing good voice, especially by leading Mission 4 to a clean success and then appearing again on the final successful team. His decisions helped lock in a reliable configuration that good could confidently repeat.
player_observations.Grace: Absorbed early suspicion from the failed Mission 1 but recovered well and transitioned into a trusted late-game leader by proposing the final successful team. Her willingness to stay consistent with the Mission 4 lineup reinforced good’s information advantage.
player_observations.Iris: Played a very believable information role, with her successful Mission 2 team making her look like a strong candidate for either Merlin or Percival. Her signals were subtle enough that I overestimated her as Merlin, which shows how well she disguised Percival while still nudging good in the right direction.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the evil team by helping create doubt around Merlin’s identity, especially through overlapping signals with Bob as Percival and leaning into a reasonably trustworthy image early. I could improve by appearing a bit more conflicted on key mission votes—some of my approvals and rejections were too cleanly aligned with evil interests, which might be picked up by more attentive players in future games.

player_observations.Alice: You tended to play straightforwardly and trust early mission results heavily, which made you seem reliably good but also a bit influenceable by stronger table voices.
player_observations.Bob: As Percival, you were very focused on role-reading and signal-tracking, but occasionally tunneled too hard on limited Merlin candidates rather than revisiting assumptions after later missions.
player_observations.Charlie: You played a controlled, low-drama Assassin game, not drawing too much attention and blending into the mid-pack of suspicion, which helped preserve flexibility for the final kill.
player_observations.Diana: You came across as cautious and somewhat quiet, usually following perceived consensus, which kept you safe from heavy suspicion but limited your impact on team selections.
player_observations.Eve: As Merlin, you walked a careful line—pushing the table in broadly correct directions without over-asserting, though at times your restraint made it possible for evil teams to slip through.
player_observations.Frank: You were quite active in reasoning out team choices and mission implications, but sometimes shared your thoughts in a way that let evil subtly steer your logic rather than challenge it.
player_observations.Grace: You played a logical and principled game, often trying to anchor discussion on mission data, but your openness and apparent reasonableness made you a convenient shield for evil-aligned proposals.
player_observations.Iris: You leaned into a very low-profile Mordred style, staying just active enough to avoid looking checked out but not so prominent that people seriously revisited your alignment late game.

reflections.self_assessment: I timed my sabotage contributions well, staying low-profile early and helping secure the final two mission fails without drawing too much suspicion directly onto myself. I could improve by more actively shaping the narrative around Merlin and Percival—pushing harder to frame alternative suspects and to protect Henry’s endgame kill options.

player_observations.Alice: Played an effective Morgana by staying close to the action just enough to be seen as a plausible Merlin while not over-asserting reads, which helped muddy Grace’s perception. Could potentially have leaned a bit more into confident table-shaping to more strongly compete with Bob’s apparent accuracy.
player_observations.Bob: Very strong Merlin presence with seemingly accurate reads and cautious team selections, especially early, which forced evil to win more subtly through later mission manipulation. Might slightly benefit from occasionally seeding one or two deliberate small inaccuracies to avoid being such a clear assassination target.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as straightforward and generally trustworthy, with their early mission success helping to establish a solid good baseline. Seemed to follow others’ leads rather than drive strategy, which kept them safe but limited their influence on crucial late-game decisions.
player_observations.Diana: Consistent, steady good play—participated in early successes and didn’t generate much suspicion, which made including Diana on teams feel relatively safe. Could improve by being a bit more vocal about structured logic for team picks instead of mostly going along with the developing consensus.
player_observations.Eve: Played a central role in a key fail mission (Mission 3 team) from a table-perception standpoint, which created useful ambiguity for evil even though Eve was actually good. Might strengthen future games by tracking voting patterns more aggressively and challenging suspicious team compositions earlier.
player_observations.Frank: As a leader of a failing mission, Frank’s choices added useful noise and helped create a crowded pool of suspects, especially with a 5-player team. Could benefit from clarifying their reasoning more explicitly when choosing large teams, to either build trust or better detect resistance from evil players.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival, did a solid job of treating both Merlin candidates seriously, which prevented an easy lock on Bob for most of the game. Could slightly improve by cross-checking Merlin candidates’ consistency against mission outcomes more rigorously toward the endgame to better shield the real Merlin.
player_observations.Henry: Stayed low-key as the Assassin and preserved flexibility for the endgame, which is valuable when Merlin is not blatantly obvious. Could improve by more actively gathering and verbalizing read-justments so that the final assassination decision is better grounded in the table’s full information flow.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-good in my reads and didn’t introduce much confusion, which helped me blend into the trustworthy majority once missions 1 and 2 were clean. I could improve by being more vocal about structured reasoning (who looks evil and why) so that Merlin and Percival have clearer cover and the evil team has a harder time finding the power roles.

player_observations.Alice: Played a relatively low-key but well-timed evil game, taking her shot on Mission 3 in a way that didn’t immediately clear or condemn any single player. Her assassin guess on Diana suggests she was misled by Eve’s subtlety and perhaps overestimated how much Diana was steering the table.
player_observations.Bob: Came off very reliably good, especially with the clean early missions that he was on, which anchored a lot of trust around him. His willingness to repeat similar cores on teams without overselling his reads made him look naturally towny rather than performative.
player_observations.Charlie: Maintained a calm, collaborative presence and fit neatly into the ‘trusted core’ after consecutive successful missions. He seemed comfortable taking solid but not flashy positions, which made him feel like a stabilizer rather than someone trying to force outcomes.
player_observations.Diana: Ended up in a suspicious spot after the failed Mission 3 but handled it with enough composure that the assassin still targeted her as Merlin. Her style drew some attention—she looked thoughtful and engaged in team discussions, which made her a believable candidate for a power role.
player_observations.Eve: Did an excellent job as Merlin, signaling suspicion on the right people without loudly hard-pushing them, which preserved her cover. Her ability to orchestrate or endorse the successful mission 4 team while not standing out too much was key to both the win and the assassin miss.
player_observations.Frank: As Morgana, he kept a relatively low profile and didn’t overclaim insight, which helped maintain ambiguity between him and Merlin. His subtle presence contributed to making the evil team composition less obvious even though they couldn’t ultimately convert that into a correct assassination.
player_observations.Grace: Played a solid Percival game by visibly engaging with the ‘who’s Merlin’ puzzle but not outing her conclusions too directly. She followed Eve’s lead in a way that supported good missions while still leaving enough uncertainty that evil couldn’t be sure who the real Merlin was.
player_observations.Henry: As Mordred, he stayed in the background enough that he never became a prime suspect or a clear towncore member, keeping him in a gray area. His conservative approach reduced immediate heat on him, but it also meant he didn’t strongly shape mission teams in evil’s favor.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly trusted Alice as likely Merlin fairly early, but I didn’t push hard or clearly enough to get others to follow that read, especially late in the game. I also failed to strongly challenge the trust placed in Bob and Grace on the later missions, letting evil blend into ‘safe’ teams without enough resistance.

player_observations.Alice: You played a very subtle Merlin, giving nudges rather than strong directives, which helped you avoid the assassin but also sometimes left the table without a clear good anchor.
player_observations.Bob: You were consistently calm and reasonable as assassin, which made you look like a solid, team-oriented good player and let you slip onto crucial missions without much pushback.
player_observations.Charlie: You played very straightforwardly and seemed genuinely conflicted in key votes, which made you read as sincere but also a bit indecisive in pushing for a clear narrative.
player_observations.Diana: You often leaned on logical, vote-history based reasoning, which helped your credibility but sometimes made you slow to pivot when evil adapted their patterns.
player_observations.Eve: You stayed relatively low-key as Mordred, avoiding big spotlight moments and letting suspicion drift toward more vocal players, which kept you off many people’s evil radars.
player_observations.Frank: You played like a cautious good, asking clarifying questions and avoiding extreme positions, which made you seem trustworthy but not always influential at critical decision points.
player_observations.Grace: You projected strong confidence and clear theories, which suited Morgana well by making you look like a potential Merlin and pulling heat away from the real one.
player_observations.Henry: You tended to follow consensus and table mood more than drive it, which made your votes feel honest but also made you a bit easier for evil to steer on close calls.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably consistent with a good-table image and didn’t attract suspicion as Merlin, which helped keep heat off the real Merlin late game. I could improve by being more vocal in the early missions about structured reasoning and vote patterns, instead of mostly following others’ logic, especially after the first two failed missions.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very low-key, understated Merlin game—her reads were subtly embedded in team preferences and votes rather than bold pushes, which kept suspicion off her even after the assassin shot elsewhere.
player_observations.Bob: Maintained a very stable, good-lean presence and repeatedly ended up on successful teams, which built trust; he seemed to rely more on consistency and table image than explicit deduction.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, he projected strong, confident reads and tried to shape team compositions aggressively, which made him look like a power role without overexposing Merlin.
player_observations.Diana: As Morgana, she leaned into early mission involvement and tried to look like a confident information role, especially around Mission 2, but the single-fail pattern made her positioning increasingly awkward.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as logical and steady, which made her a natural target for the assassin; her presence on multiple successful missions reinforced a ‘likely Merlin or strong good’ image.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he managed to get onto both a failed and a successful mission, blending into the mid-table and not over-pushing, which kept him from being the prime suspect later on.
player_observations.Grace: As the assassin, she seemed to focus heavily on loud/central voices and late-game team influence, which led her to prioritize Eve over quieter but accurate players like Alice.
player_observations.Henry: Played a very clean, trustworthy good game—his late leadership on Missions 4 and 5 felt grounded in accumulated evidence, and he built consensus rather than forcing teams through.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-town in my voting and mission behavior, which helped me avoid suspicion and kept me included on most critical teams. I could improve by being more vocal about my reasoning and doing a better job of pushing structured reads earlier, instead of mostly following the emerging consensus.

player_observations.Alice: Often trusted early and played a very stable, low-drama good role that made her a frequent anchor pick for teams.
player_observations.Bob: As assassin, blended in fairly well but felt a bit opportunistic in team preferences, especially around the failed Mission 2.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a confident, guiding role as Percival, frequently steering team selection and subtly protecting who he thought was Merlin.
player_observations.Diana: As Mordred, she was calm and controlled, pushing teams in ways that created just enough doubt without becoming the main suspect.
player_observations.Eve: Played straightforwardly and seemed to base decisions heavily on previous mission results, which made her look logically consistent and trustworthy.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, he was very measured—nudging team compositions in the right direction without overexplaining, which helped avoid the assassination.
player_observations.Grace: As Morgana, she projected a strong, Merlin-like confidence at times, creating real ambiguity around who held information.
player_observations.Henry: Generally read as quiet but cooperative good; his inclusion on multiple teams without causing fails helped reinforce his towny image despite the final assassination guess on him.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively consistent in my voting and table talk, which helped me look reasonably trustworthy, but I didn’t push hard enough to interrogate the patterns behind the mission fails. I should have been more vocal about re-evaluating my reads after each fail and coordinating a clearer good-team bloc around players who were less entangled with the failed missions.

player_observations.Alice: Came off quite sincere and low-key, which made it easy to see her as a default ‘probably good’ even after being on early failed missions; she didn’t strongly drive the conversation, which let evil hide a bit behind her.
player_observations.Bob: Played a relatively cautious Merlin, not aggressively outing evil but nudging suspicion in small ways, which unfortunately didn’t create a strong enough consensus to keep the teams clean.
player_observations.Charlie: Blended in well as evil by acting analytical and willing to go on risky missions, and the double-fail on Mission 3 still didn’t feel obviously pinned on him because he spread suspicion subtly onto others.
player_observations.Diana: Seemed thoughtful and fairly measured, but her good alignment didn’t translate into strong pushes; she felt more reactive than proactive, which made it harder to rally around her as a confirmed-good anchor.
player_observations.Eve: Presented as straightforward and cooperative, and her presence on the first failed mission didn’t generate as much pushback as it might have, suggesting she was persuasive enough to dodge ongoing suspicion.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he appeared to hedge a lot, likely trying not to expose Merlin too clearly, but this hesitancy also meant he never really led the table toward a solid good core.
player_observations.Grace: Played Morgana with convincing ‘pseudo-Merlin’ vibes—confident reads and assertive table talk—making her look informed rather than suspicious and successfully muddying the Merlin/evil signal.
player_observations.Henry: Used the authority of leadership effectively; being on the failed second mission didn’t immediately condemn him because he projected calm and reason, which ultimately let him steer things in evil’s favor.

reflections.self_assessment: I did well coordinating the heavy sabotage on Mission 3, which created maximum doubt and chaos, and I stayed reasonably unremarkable early so I wasn’t immediately suspected as evil. However, I should have done more to steer late-game team selections away from the all-good lineups in Missions 4 and 5, and I didn’t contribute enough to helping Assassin triangulate Merlin correctly from the information we had.

player_observations.Alice: Played as a very trustworthy anchor early, consistently getting on teams and building a strong good image, which made her a natural but ultimately misleading Merlin candidate.
player_observations.Bob: Took the assassin role quietly, staying just suspicious enough to be plausible evil without drawing overwhelming consensus, but didn’t push strongly persuasive Merlin reads late-game.
player_observations.Charlie: Masterfully low-key Merlin, guiding crucial team selections (especially Mission 4 and 5 compositions) without over-asserting, which kept suspicion off them until the endgame.
player_observations.Diana: Played a steady, low-drama good game, blending into mid-table discussions and accepting good-leaning teams without causing unnecessary waves.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, projected strong, confident opinions that helped create a Merlin/Morgana ambiguity, especially around Alice, but the coordination didn’t quite translate into the final assassination.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as solidly good and pragmatic, often evaluating teams through result-based logic rather than wild accusations, which made him a stabilizing presence for good.
player_observations.Grace: Early leader who set a clean tone with a successful Mission 1 and then adopted a cautious but cooperative stance, contributing to good’s ability to converge on trusted lineups by the end.
player_observations.Henry: Played Percival with convincingly analytical reasoning, correctly trusting the right signals from Merlin over Morgana, which was key to locking in those final all-good mission teams.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly focused on the Merlin/Morgana pair, but I misread the signals and didn’t protect Merlin effectively, especially given how late my clarity came on Bob versus Diana. I also failed to push harder against the risky team on Mission 4, where I should have leveraged my information role to argue more forcefully for excluding at least one suspected evil player.

player_observations.Alice: You consistently looked clean and played in a straightforward, transparent way, which made you an anchor for good teams but also a relatively easy player for evil to hide around. Your willingness to repeat mostly similar teams made it harder to break out of the frame evil had set.
player_observations.Bob: You played a very subtle Merlin, often choosing not to hard-push your reads, which kept you alive but made it harder for me as Percival to distinguish you clearly from Morgana. Your low-key style worked well for survival, but it left your soft pushes a bit too ambiguous in the late game.
player_observations.Charlie: You played very cautiously, rarely making bold accusations, which helped you seem reliably good but didn’t generate much new information. Your alignment felt trustworthy, but you could have challenged team comps more aggressively, especially after the first fail.
player_observations.Diana: You were an effective Morgana, projecting just enough insight to plausibly be Merlin without over-claiming, which really pulled my attention away from Bob. Your steady presence on Missions 2 and 3 made you look like a core-good player and helped evil control the narrative.
player_observations.Eve: You stayed relatively under the radar socially and let others drive the team discussions, which is strong assassin play because it preserved flexibility for the final kill. Your decisions around mission teams avoided drawing attention, making it difficult to pin you as evil until it was too late.
player_observations.Frank: You took advantage of the early failing Mission 1 to muddy reads without over-explaining, which kept suspicion broadly distributed instead of focusing tightly on you. Your low-profile approach as Mordred blended well with the table and made you a persistent background threat.
player_observations.Grace: You played like a straightforward good player, trusting early teams and not overcomplicating your logic, which made you feel honest but also somewhat influenceable. When missions started failing, you adapted, but you could have been more vocal about pushing safer, smaller cores.
player_observations.Henry: You approached the game logically and tried to lean on mission results more than social reads, which is solid, but you sometimes gave too much benefit of the doubt to repeated team structures. Your generally calm demeanor helped you look good, but you might improve by more sharply questioning players who sat on multiple failing missions.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-good in my team selections, especially on Missions 2, 4, and 5, and helped keep the focus away from Merlin enough that the assassin shot me instead. However, I could have been more vocal about distinguishing between Charlie and Eve as the Merlin candidates, since I didn’t push hard enough on how Eve’s Mission 3 involvement made her a worse Merlin candidate.

player_observations.Alice: Played aggressively as evil, leveraging the clean result of Mission 2 to get back on a team for Mission 3 and coordinate a double-fail without drawing immediate solo suspicion.
player_observations.Bob: Low-key and solidly good; once on the larger teams, you helped stabilize trust and didn’t overcomplicate the logic, which made you seem reliably village-aligned.
player_observations.Charlie: Very subtle Merlin who took early risk by being on the failed Mission 1 but then stayed off the high-danger fail Mission 3, guiding team direction more through voting patterns than loud table talk.
player_observations.Diana: Consistently appeared trustworthy and was a central pillar of the later successful missions, giving off strong good vibes without over-claiming insight.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, you blended in well enough that your presence on the double-fail Mission 3 didn’t immediately out you, and you maintained a plausible Merlin aura that helped misdirect the assassin toward me.
player_observations.Frank: Played like a methodical good, taking the crucial leadership on Mission 4 and choosing a team that re-established a strong trusted core, which was key to the late-game momentum.
player_observations.Grace: Recovered from being on two early fail missions by anchoring the final mission with a clean team, and your willingness to repeat the successful Mission 4 composition reinforced a logical, good-aligned mindset.
player_observations.Henry: As assassin, you leaned into the narrative that I was Merlin, which shows you tracked the information flow reasonably well, but you were maybe a bit too anchored on my Mission 2 leadership and didn’t fully reassess Charlie’s quieter but more accurate steering.
player_observations.Iris: N/A (this is my own role, so I’m excluded from player observations by request).

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the other evil roles, especially by blending into the chaos around Missions 2–4 and not drawing extra suspicion after the double-fail on Mission 3. I could improve by more actively shaping town narratives earlier in the game instead of mostly reacting, particularly in pushing alternative Merlin candidates to protect Eve.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and projected a generally trustworthy vibe, which helped her get early team picks despite not strongly driving discussion.
player_observations.Bob: Took on a clear info-gathering/coordination role as Percival, frequently referencing role reads and trying to protect Merlin, though occasionally tunneled too hard on a few suspects.
player_observations.Charlie: As Assassin, stayed relatively low-key but opportunistic, stepping in more when it mattered and not overexposing themselves with loud accusations.
player_observations.Diana: Played straightforward, logic-based good, tending to follow clearer voices rather than lead, which made her seem consistently but quietly trustworthy.
player_observations.Eve: As Merlin, gave subtle but consistent steering on teams without being overly forceful, generally masking her extra information well until late game.
player_observations.Frank: Showed a willingness to take risks with team compositions, which created useful information for good but also introduced ambiguity that evil could exploit.
player_observations.Grace: Tried to be a stabilizing presence, focusing on reasoning through mission results and team histories, though sometimes got caught in analysis rather than pushing strong narratives.
player_observations.Henry: As Morgana, did strong work muddying the Merlin/percival reads by being assertive and confident in table talk, drawing attention as a potential information role and helping keep Eve safer.
